Despite your furious attempts to control the airwaves, CBS has footage of South Vietnamese forces abandoning their posts, of terrified people flooding into Saigon, of Kỳ delivering a rambling address blaming the United States for \"abandoning its promises\". All of this points to one central fact, an inevitability borne of innumerable failures—South Vietnam is collapsing. Head in your hands, you think about the billions wasted and the hundreds of thousands of lives lost. Then you think of the election, your legacy, and what a damning indictment this represents of your political program. You were elected in 1968 to get America out of the war, to preserve some semblance of American honor. The only way you can scrounge anything now is if you can somehow stop the advance until the Election. His routine is much the same as it was in '64. He boohoos about Vietnam and \"America's international reputation\". He cries about the crushing weight of taxes and \"out-of-control federal expenditures\". The only innovation at all is his selection of the moderate Senator Chuck Percy as his running mate, something you assume is meant to prevent Rockefeller's men from splitting as they did eight years ago. You'd very much like to beat Goldwater by a greater margin than Lyndon, to savage this tired performance like a New York theatre critic would. Anything to crack his image as a decent man of principles. It's after you authorize a break-in of his daughter Joanne's Arizona home that you discover what you are looking for. In 1955, while she was at Arizona State University, Joanne became pregnant. Using his money and connections, Goldwater arranged for her to receive an illegal abortion in Virginia. After authorizing a break-in to the office of his daughter Joanne's Arizona home, you find your evidence. In 1955, while she was at Arizona State University, Joanne became pregnant. Using his money and connections, Goldwater arranged for her to receive an illegal abortion in Virginia. Though available in a few states, the procedure remains illegal in most others. A growing public movement led by the Catholic Church and various evangelicals has been trying to counter an effort by a few radicals to make it widely available. This could not just shatter Goldwater's credibility, it could ruin his and his daughter's life. It was the result of a Republican Party that has forgotten its roots, that has been taken over by confidence men. You turn up your chin and give a grin that conveys not confidence but a kind of brittle anxiety. It seems the whole country feels the same. The press note your rictus grin, your jagged enthusiasm, your white-knuckled determination to get through all this tawdry sentimentality. When will you break, they mutter. When will you admit that this is no real win and you have no real mandate? You are determined not to let the bastards see you bleed, but each day it becomes harder to prevent your guts from spilling out through your fingers. You sought this Office because you thought you could embody this nation's yearning for redemptive change, but what have you actually changed? Whose soul have you redeemed?", "likelihood": 1 } }, { "model": "campaign_trail.question", "pk": 18725, "fields": { "priority": 0, "description": "Your jackass Treasury Secretary, John Connally, storms into your office one day unannounced. It's Bretton-Woods, he says, ignoring your obvious anger. It's the doll-ah. For years, he claims, foreign goods in foreign currencies have remained cheap against dollar goods. Current economic instability will continue unless you let him blow the system up, starting with a devaluation of the dollar. He outlines a strategy to pressure trading partners, but you're barely paying attention. He's so goddamn cocky. Unlike him, you keep a finger on the pulse of your allies. By devaluing the dollar, you'll piss off half the developed world as well as the unions—who are already on the verge of rebellion because of inflation. The question is, do you support them or do you want Connally's fat ass to continue darkening your doorstep?", "likelihood": 1 } }, { "model": "campaign_trail.question", "pk": 18739, "fields": { "priority": 0, "description": "Your beleaguered, crisis-rattled Treasury Secretary Sargent Shriver requests an urgent meeting with you to discuss the economy. After days of trying to avoid him, you finally acquiesce, only to find yourself assaulted with all manner of charts and graphs and your brother-in-law's pained smile. The economy, he begins, is not stabilizing. Consumer confidence is near record lows. Corporate profits have stalled due to stiff competition abroad. Inflation is bad and will only continue to get worse. You feel yourself begin to grow irritated—why is Shriver bothering you with this when the economy is his job—but he continues. He has no power to mitigate these forces without a creative use of your emergency declaration powers. He needs you to strengthen his office or, well, he looks at you sheepishly. The situation is untenable. He'll need to resign. ", "likelihood": 1 } }, { "model": "campaign_trail.question", "pk": 18753, "fields": { "priority": 0, "description": "The chickens of John Connally's dollar devaluation come home to roost within days of his return. Various UAW chapters have already revoked their endorsements. Protests are growing fierce. Worst of all, there is a threat of nationwide strikes. Led by Walter Reuther, the UAW demands an across-the-board increase in their wages or they will force a work stoppage in these final days before the Election. You plead with Reuther about how this could hand the Election to the Republicans, but he doesn't seem to care. The situation is too far gone. There's lives at stake. Is this really victory?" } }, { "model": "campaign_trail.answer_feedback", "pk": 15690, "fields": { "answer": 15689, "candidate": 80, "answer_feedback": "You wait for a reply but none comes. The silence taunts you, infuriates you. You scarcely notice as a writhing swarm bursts free from the belly of a dying Republican Party. These are followed by reports of fraggings, of soldiers and reservists going AWOL, of gunfights and skirmishes more intense than anything seen since 1968. In the evening, you sit in the dark, illuminated by nothing but the television screen. Though Walter Cronkite's voice sounds disgusted as it reads about flag-draped caskets and dying Vietnamese children, you note that the North's advance has slowed to a crawl. It will not reach Saigon before the Election. You try to continue focusing on this pyrrhic victory and not the portrait of Jack behind you." } }, { "model": "campaign_trail.answer_feedback", "pk": 16123, "fields": { "answer": 16122, "candidate": 80, "answer_feedback": "Vietnam is turned into a hell on earth by American planes whose bombs demolish villages and erase families. An untold number of children die at your hands. Hundreds of thousands are left with scars, amputations, and traumas that will haunt them for the rest of their lives. None of this succeeds in halting the North's advance. It does not even succeed in slowing it. All you have accomplished with your latest impotent tantrum is damning your own soul. As the NVA reaches the outskirts of Saigon, you find yourself avoiding the room where your brother's painting hangs. You could not bear to look at him." } }, { "model": "campaign_trail.answer_feedback", "pk": 16127, "fields": { "answer": 16126, "candidate": 80, "answer_feedback": "Riots follow news of your re-deployments into the South. These are followed by reports of fraggings, of soldiers and reservists going AWOL, of gunfights and skirmishes more intense than anything seen since 1968. In the evening, you sit in the dark, illuminated by nothing but the television screen, and learn that all this suffering, all this carnage, has been for nothing. Red continues to fill the map, even as Americans and Vietnamese alike perish at record speed. You cannot help but feel the sensation of being watched at this moment. You do not turn to face the painting of your brother." } }, { "model": "campaign_trail.answer_feedback", "pk": 16133, "fields": { "answer": 16132, "candidate": 80, "answer_feedback": "An effort to unite liberal delegates around a candidate that Byrd can beat fails. "fields": { "candidate": 83, "state": 147, "state_multiplier": 0.03 } } ] campaignTrail_temp.jet_data = [{ "nicknames": { "80": "Robert Kennedy", "81": "The Republicans", "82": "Greys", "83": "Fairies" }, "mapping_enabled": false, "mapping_data": {} } ] campaignTrail_temp.candidate_image_url = campaignTrail_temp.kennedyPic; campaignTrail_temp.running_mate_image_url = 'https://i.imgur.com/T57rMr5.png'; campaignTrail_temp.candidate_last_name = 'Kennedy'; campaignTrail_temp.running_mate_last_name = 'Long'; let closeSurrogateFlag = 0; function ctsAchievement(achievement, difficultyChecker = true){ if ((difficultyChecker && campaignTrail_temp.difficulty_level_multiplier<=1)||!difficultyChecker) if(campaignTrail_temp.CTS){ unlockAchievement(achievement); } } function unlockAchievement(name) { const ach = findAchievementByName(name); if (ach == null) { console.log("There is no achievement with the name '" + name + "'"); return; } if (cheatsActive && ach.cannotBeCheated) { console.log(`Would unlock '${name}' but won't because cheating!`); return; } if (unlockedAch[name] == null) { //alert("ACHIEVEMENT UNLOCKED: " + name); } showAchievement(name); unlockedAch[name] = ach; localStorage.setItem("unlockedAch", JSON.stringify(unlockedAch)); addAllAchievements(); } function showAchievement(achievementKey) { const achievement = campaignTrail_temp.achievements[achievementKey]; if(achievementKey == "Kenosis
⠀"){ var sound = new Audio('https://audio.jukehost.co.uk/LfMOoqTNbyGgxqCEVeC7yN87gywDlI27'); sound.volume = 0.3; sound.play(); } // Create the achievement box const box = document.createElement('div'); box.style.position = 'fixed'; box.style.right = '20px'; box.style.backgroundColor = '#4CAF50'; box.style.color = 'white'; box.style.width = '250px'; box.style.height = '110px'; box.style.textAlign = 'center'; box.style.padding = '10px 10px'; box.style.borderRadius = '8px'; box.style.fontSize = '18px'; box.style.boxShadow = '0 4px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2)'; box.style.opacity = '0'; box.style.transition = 'opacity 1s ease-in-out'; box.style.zIndex = '1000'; box.style.display = 'flex'; box.style.alignItems = 'center'; box.style.gap = '15px'; box.style.backgroundImage = 'url("https://i.imgur.com/39bg8Op.png")'; box.style.backgroundPosition = 'center'; box.style.boxShadow = '0 4px 12px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3)'; const existingBoxes = document.querySelectorAll('.achievement-popup'); const offset = existingBoxes.length * 132; box.style.bottom = `${20 + offset}px`; const img = document.createElement('img'); img.src = achievement.image; img.alt = achievementKey; img.style.width = '100px'; img.style.height = '100px'; const text = document.createElement('div'); const cleanedAchievementKey = achievementKey.replace('

popularity.', id: 'PERCY_A'} function updateCandidates(type, amt){ if(e.noCounter < 20){ if(type == "econ" && amt>0){ // Good Econ for RFK // adds if(rockefeller_active == 1){ opponents.rockefeller += (1.5*amt) } // subs if(reagan_active == 1){ opponents.reagan -= (0.5*amt) } } if(type == "econ" && amt<0){ // Bad Econ for RFK // adds if(goldwater_active == 1){ opponents.goldwater += 1 } if(reagan_active == 1){ opponents.reagan += (-0.4*amt) } if(hughes_active == 1){ opponents.hughes += 1 } // subs } if(type == "cult" && amt>0){ // Good Cult for RFK // adds // if(nixon_active == 1){ // opponents.nixon += 1 // } if(percy_active == 1){ opponents.percy += (1*amt) } if(lindsay_active == 1){ opponents.lindsay += 1 } // subs if(agnew_active == 1){ opponents.agnew -= 0.3 } if(hughes_active == 1){ opponents.hughes -= 0.5 } } if(type == "cult" && amt<0){ // Bad Cult for RFK // adds if(agnew_active == 1){ opponents.agnew += (-1*amt) } if(reagan_active == 1){ opponents.reagan += (-0.4*amt) } if(lindsay_active == 1){ opponents.lindsay += (1*amt) } // backlash bumpkins if(nixon_active == 1){ opponents.nixon += 1 } if(yorty_active == 1){ opponents.yorty += (-1.5*amt) } if(hughes_active == 1){ opponents.hughes += 1.5 } } if(type == "ach"){ // Achievement for RFK // adds if(rockefeller_active == 1){ opponents.rockefeller += 0.5 } if(percy_active == 1){ opponents.percy += 0.5 } if(goldwater_active == 1){ opponents.goldwater += 0.5 } // subs } if(type == "sou" && amt>0){ // Southern Supp for RFK // adds if(rockefeller_active == 1){ opponents.rockefeller += 0.3 } if(lindsay_active == 1){ opponents.lindsay += 0.3 } if(nixon_active == 1){ } if(yorty_active == 1){ opponents.yorty -= 0.2 } // subs } if(type == "sou" && amt<0){ // let questionConfig = { attributes: true, childList: true, subtree: true }; function updateQuestions(mutationList, observer) { const answers = document.getElementsByClassName("game_answers"); for (let i = 0; i < answers.length; i++) { const answer = answers[i]; if (answer.classList.contains("done")) { continue; } answer.classList.add("done"); let answerObject = campaignTrail_temp.answers_json.filter((x) => x.pk == answer.value)[0]; if (answerObject.fields.condition != null) { answer.disabled = !(eval(answerObject.fields.condition)); } } } const questionObserver = new MutationObserver(updateQuestions); const mapContainer = document.getElementById('map_container') questionObserver.observe(gameWindowNode, questionConfig); bumpkinChange(candidateName) { bumpkin = candidateName if(candidateName == "Wallace"){ var id = e.candidate_json.map(p=>p.pk).indexOf(82) e.candidate_json[id].fields.first_name = "George" e.candidate_issue_score_json.map(p=>p.pk).indexOf(50) e.candidate_issue_score_json[id].fields.issue_score = (-0.4+wallaceveep); } else if(candidateName == "Rarick"){ var id = e.candidate_issue_score_json.map(p=>p.pk).indexOf(49) e.candidate_issue_score_json[id].fields.issue_score = -1.13; var id = e.candidate_issue_score_json.map(p=>p.pk).indexOf(50) e.candidate_issue_score_json[id].fields.issue_score = -1.13; } else if(candidateName == "Perot"){ var id = e.candidate_json.map(p=>p.pk).indexOf(82) e.candidate_json[id].fields.first_name = "H.R." e.candidate_json[id].fields.last_name = "Perot" e.candidate_json[id].fields.color_hex = "#667561" } else if(candidateName == "Unpledged"){ var id = e.candidate_json.map(p=>p.pk).indexOf(82) e.candidate_json[id].fields.first_name = "" e.candidate_json[id].fields.last_name = "Unpledged" e.candidate_json[id].fields.color_hex = "#c2bf6d" } } function fairyChange(candidateName) { fairy = candidateName if(candidateName == "McCarthy"){ var id = e.candidate_json.map(p=>p.pk).indexOf(83) e.candidate_json[id].fields.first_name = "Eugene" e.candidate_json[id].fields.last_name = "McCarthy" e.candidate_json[id].fields.color_hex = "#85c98b" } else if(candidateName == "Spock"){ var id = e.candidate_json.map(p=>p.pk).indexOf(83) e.candidate_json[id].fields.first_name = "Benjamin" e.candidate_json[id].fields.last_name = "Spock" e.candidate_json[id].fields.color_hex = "#c94040" } else if(candidateName == "McCloskey"){ var id = e.candidate_json.map(p=>p.pk).indexOf(83) e.candidate_json[id].fields.first_name = "Pete" e.candidate_json[id].fields.last_name = "McCloskey" e.candidate_json[id].fields.color_hex = "#a17d9c" } else if(candidateName == "Jarvis"){ var id = e.candidate_json.map(p=>p.pk).indexOf(83) e.candidate_json[id].fields.first_name = "Howard" e.candidate_json[id].fields.last_name = "Jarvis" e.candidate_json[id].fields.color_hex = "#dea947" } } let colorObserver = new MutationObserver(colorFunction); function colorFunction() { colorObserver.disconnect(); if(e.altcolors){ var id = e.candidate_json.map(p=>p.pk).indexOf(80) e.candidate_json[id].fields.color_hex = "#36558a" var id = e.candidate_json.map(p=>p.pk).indexOf(81) e.candidate_json[id].fields.color_hex = "#9c2c2c" const style_overwrite = document.createElement("style"); style_overwrite.innerHTML = ` #menu_container { background-color: #314746; } #overall_result_container { background-color: #314746; } #state_info h3 { background: #EDF3F7; border-bottom-color: #548EAD; }` ; document.head.appendChild(style_overwrite); } else{ const style_overwrite = document.createElement("style"); style_overwrite.innerHTML = ` #DBD0D0; } .inner_inner_window h3 { background-color: #DBD0D0; } #question_form input[type="radio"]:checked + label { background: #F7EAEA; border-bottom-color: #BC7474; }` ; document.head.appendChild(style_overwrite); } console.log(e.difficultychosen); if (e.difficultychosen == 1) { // Beginner // disable vietnam falling and econ crash } else if (e.difficultychosen == 3) { // Difficult // disable getting shot at } else if (e.difficultychosen == 4) { // Challenge // disable getting shot at cult_support -= 1 eminence -= 1 south_support -= 1 economy -= 2 //updateCandidates("cult", -0.5) //updateCandidates("econ", -0.5) } else if (e.difficultychosen == 2) { // Normal // nothing } refreshSurrogates() } colorObserver.observe(document.body, { childList: true, subtree: true }); function changechart() { if (document.getElementById("overall_result") != null) { var overallthing = document.getElementById("overall_result").innerHTML; if } } } function initializeTooltips() { var tooltipContainers = document.querySelectorAll('.tooltip-container'); tooltipContainers.forEach(function(container) { var tooltip = container.querySelector('.tooltip'); container.addEventListener('mouseover', function(event) { if (event.target === container) { tooltip.style.visibility = 'visible'; // Make it visible tooltip.style.opacity = '1'; } }); container.addEventListener('mouseout', function(event) { if (event.target === container) { tooltip.style.visibility = 'hidden'; // Hide it tooltip.style.opacity = '0'; } }); }); } window.setInterval(changechart, 200); var pictureDict = { 0: "https://i.imgur.com/KFchink.png", 1: "https://i.imgur.com/2hZEP5I.png", 2: "https://i.imgur.com/Bvkpip3.png", 3: "https://i.imgur.com/KU68xXd.png", 4: "https://i.imgur.com/KFchink.png", //VN Checkpoint 5: "https://i.imgur.com/mrJX5Kt.png", 6: "https://i.imgur.com/bIMBmdA.png", 7: "https://i.imgur.com/4KrrPMs.png", 8: "https://i.imgur.com/kqsv5tC.png", 9: "https://i.imgur.com/oU6a69N.png", 10: "https://i.imgur.com/DbymHHc.png", 11: "https://i.imgur.com/LW6cpLy.png", 12: "https://i.imgur.com/xFyIf3o.png", 13: "https://i.imgur.com/HE78JiM.png", 14: "https://i.imgur.com/KFchink.png", // VN checkpoint 15: "https://i.imgur.com/U1gA4yz.png", 16: "https://i.imgur.com/I9W5Npi.png", 17: "https://i.imgur.com/ZUUMbne.png", 18: "https://i.imgur.com/lZ7GKtJ.png", 19: "https://i.imgur.com/eEcDqUh.png", 20: "https://i.imgur.com/Fhz2yW7.png", 21: "https://i.imgur.com/KFchink.png", // VN checkpoint 22: "https://i.imgur.com/KFchink.png", 23: "https://i.imgur.com/BCPNTEd.png", 24: "https://i.imgur.com/xLs4QWp.png", // DNC 25: "https://i.imgur.com/L6TLiAY.png", 26: "https://i.imgur.com/KFchink.png", 27: "https://i.imgur.com/KFchink.png", 28: "https://i.imgur.com/eWAwxYg.png", 29: "https://i.imgur.com/jQkAx6g.png", }; function preloadImages(pictureDict) { for (var key in pictureDict) { var img = new Image(); img.src = pictureDict[key]; } } preloadImages(pictureDict); async function handleFooter() { var gameWindow = document.getElementById('game_window'); addHeadquarterButton() var existingFooter = document.getElementById('new_footer'); if (existingFooter) { return; } var oldCandidatePic = document.getElementById('candidate_pic'); if(oldCandidatePic){ var candidatePicSrc = oldCandidatePic.src; oldCandidatePic.remove(); } else{ return } var oldRunningMatePic = document.getElementById('running_mate_pic'); if(oldRunningMatePic) { var runningMatePicSrc = oldRunningMatePic.src; oldRunningMatePic.remove(); } else{ return } var new_footer = document.createElement("div"); new_footer.id = "new_footer"; new_footer.style.display = "flex"; new_footer.style.justifyContent = "center"; new_footer.style.alignItems = "center"; var candidatePic = createNewImageElement(candidatePicSrc, 'borderBottom'); var runningMatePic = createNewImageElement(runningMatePicSrc, 'borderBottom'); var candidateBox = createBox(candidatePic, "President", "Robert Kennedy"); var runningMateBox = createBox(runningMatePic, runningmaterole, runningmatefullname); var questionInfo = "Question " + (campaignTrail_temp.question_number + 1) + " of " + campaignTrail_temp.global_parameter_json[0].fields.question_count; var questionBox = createBoxWithTextAndPic(questionInfo, pictureDict[campaignTrail_temp.question_number]); new_footer.appendChild(candidateBox); new_footer.appendChild(questionBox); new_footer.appendChild(runningMateBox); gameWindow.appendChild(new_footer); var signDisplay = document.getElementsByClassName('inner_window_sign_display')[0]; signDisplay.style.display = "none"; }; function createNewImageElement(src, border) { var newImage = document.createElement('img'); newImage.src = src; newImage.style.height = '14em'; if (border === 'borderBottom') { newImage.style.borderBottom = '2px solid black'; } else if (border === 'borderTop') { newImage.style.borderTop = '2px solid black'; } return newImage; } function createBox(imageElement, role, text) { var container = document.createElement('div'); container.classList.add('rounded-box'); container.style.borderColor = '#1F1D19'; if(e.altcolors){ container.style.backgroundColor = '#d7dcde'; } else{ container.style.backgroundColor = '#DBD0D0'; } //container.style.backgroundImage = "url('https://i.imgur.com/timosT8.png')"; // container.style.backgroundSize = 'cover'; // //container.style.backgroundPosition = 'center'; // container.style.backgroundRepeat = 'no-repeat'; var textBox = document.createElement('div'); var textBox2 = document.createElement('div'); textBox.style.fontSize = '12px'; textBox.style.padding = '2px'; textBox.style.textAlign = 'center'; textBox.style.marginTop = '-6px'; textBox.style.marginBottom = '-12px'; textBox.innerHTML = '

' + role + '

'; textBox2.style.fontSize = '16px'; textBox2.style.padding = '2px'; textBox2.style.textAlign = 'center'; textBox2.style.marginTop = '-16px'; textBox2.style.marginBottom = '-12px'; textBox2.innerHTML = '

' + text + '

'; container.appendChild(imageElement); container.appendChild(textBox); container.appendChild(textBox2); return container; } function createBoxWithTextAndPic(text, pictureSrc) { var container = document.createElement('div'); container.classList.add('rounded-box'); container.style.borderColor = '#1F1D19'; if(e.altcolors){ container.style.backgroundColor = '#d7dcde'; } else{ container.style.backgroundColor = '#DBD0D0'; } //container.style.backgroundImage = "url('https://i.imgur.com/timosT8.png')"; // container.style.backgroundSize = 'cover'; // container.style.backgroundPosition = 'center'; // container.style.backgroundRepeat = 'no-repeat'; var textBox = document.createElement('div'); textBox.style.fontSize = '16px'; textBox.style.padding = '3px'; textBox.style.textAlign = 'center'; textBox.innerHTML = '

' + text + '

'; var pictureElement = createNewImageElement(pictureSrc, 'borderTop'); container.appendChild(textBox); container.appendChild(pictureElement); return container; } async function handleMutations(mutationsList, observer) { if (observerRunning) return; observerRunning = true; observer.disconnect(); await changeChart(processedNodes); await handleFooter(); observer.observe(document.documentElement, { childList: true, subtree: true }); observerRunning = false; } let processedNodes = new Set(); let observerRunning = false; var element = document.getElementById('controlElement'); if (!element) { let singleObserver = new MutationObserver(handleMutations); singleObserver.observe(document.documentElement, { childList: true, subtree: true }); var controlElement = document.createElement('div'); controlElement.style.display = 'none'; controlElement.id = 'controlElement'; document.body.appendChild(controlElement); } let candidateWatcherConfig = { attributes: true, childList: true, subtree: true }; const candidateObserver = new MutationObserver(onGameWindowChangeCandidates); candidateObserver.observe(gameWindowNode, candidateWatcherConfig); const electionObserver = new MutationObserver((mutations, electionObserverInstance) => { for (let mutation of mutations) { if (mutation.type === "childList") { const electionElement = document.getElementById("election_night_buttons"); if (electionElement) { const electionPlaylist = new Playlist(); const electionSong = new Song( "Dean Jones, Donna McKechnie", "Tick-Tock", "https://i.imgur.com/4aRIys9.png", "https://audio.jukehost.co.uk/D9ftBe2PIbOsrcJ2PoMberCWJSZJp6Zz" ); electionPlaylist.addSong(electionSong); changePlaylist(electionPlaylist); electionObserverInstance.disconnect(); break; } } } }); electionObserver.observe(document.body, { childList: true, subtree: true }); newHistPVP9 = ["70.8%", "14.4%", "13.7%", "1.1%"]; function onGameWindowChangeCandidates() { const resultsTableHolder = document.getElementById("overall_details_container"); if(!resultsTableHolder || resultsTableHolder.classList.contains("done")) { return; } resultsTableHolder.classList.add("done"); const resultsTable = resultsTableHolder.childNodes[3].childNodes[3].children[0]; for(let i = 0; i < resultsTable.children.length; i++) { const row = resultsTable.children[i]; let name = row.firstChild.innerText; row.insertCell(1); if(name) { name = name.replaceAll("-", "").trim(); console.log("name is:" + name) } if(i == 0) { row.children[1].innerHTML = `Running Mate`; } else { row.children[1].innerHTML = vpTable[name]; } } const resultsTableHistorical = resultsTableHolder.childNodes[5].childNodes[3].children[0]; for(let i = 0; i < resultsTableHistorical.children.length; i++) { const row = resultsTableHistorical.children[i]; let name = row.childNodes[1].innerText; row.insertCell(1); if(name) { name = name.replaceAll("-", "").trim(); } if(i == 0) { row.children[1].innerHTML = `Running Mate`; } else { row.children[1].innerHTML = vpTableHistorical[name]; } } } function addHeadquarterButton() { if(e.colorBlind){ var id = e.candidate_json.map(p=>p.pk).indexOf(80) e.candidate_json[id].fields.color_hex = "#B52D1B" var id = e.candidate_json.map(p=>p.pk).indexOf(81) e.candidate_json[id].fields.color_hex = "#2193CA" if(e.altcolors){ var id = e.candidate_json.map(p=>p.pk).indexOf(80) e.candidate_json[id].fields.color_hex = "#2193CA" var id = e.candidate_json.map(p=>p.pk).indexOf(81) e.candidate_json[id].fields.color_hex = "#B52D1B" } } // Check if the button already exists if (document.getElementById('headquarter_button')) { return; } // Find the reference button by its ID const refButton = document.getElementById('view_electoral_map'); if (!refButton) { return; } // Create a new button element const newButton = document.createElement('button'); newButton.id = 'headquarter_button'; newButton.style.marginLeft = '1.5em'; newButton.innerHTML = 'File'; // Attach the click event listener newButton.addEventListener('click', openSurrogates); // Insert the new button next to the reference button refButton.insertAdjacentElement('afterend', newButton); } const menuItemsA = [ { photo: 'https://i.imgur.com/7HEMDjv.png', text: 'J.E. Hoover
CLASS: A

// Allows absolute positioning inside menuItem.style.display = 'flex'; menuItem.style.alignItems = 'flex-start'; menuItem.style.marginBottom = '5px'; menuItem.style.backgroundColor = 'rgba(128, 142, 142, 0.5)'; text.style.fontSize = "13px"; text.innerHTML = item.text; text.style.margin = '0'; textAndButton.appendChild(text); menuItem.appendChild(photo); menuItem.appendChild(textAndButton); // Optional tooltip element with dynamic value if (item.tooltip) { const tooltipIcon = document.createElement('div'); tooltipIcon.textContent = '[?]'; // Text for the tooltip indicator tooltipIcon.style.position = 'absolute'; tooltipIcon.style.top = '5px'; tooltipIcon.style.right = '5px'; tooltipIcon.style.color = '#2CA0D2'; tooltipIcon.style.cursor = 'pointer'; tooltipIcon.style.fontSize = '11px'; // Tooltip functionality: Add hover behavior tooltipIcon.addEventListener('mouseover', () => { const tooltip = document.createElement('div'); tooltip.style.position = 'absolute'; tooltip.style.backgroundColor = '#333'; tooltip.style.color = '#fff'; tooltip.style.padding = '5px'; tooltip.style.borderRadius = '3px'; tooltip.style.fontSize = '12px'; tooltip.style.zIndex = '1000'; tooltip.style.top = `${tooltipIcon.getBoundingClientRect().top + window.scrollY + 20}px`; // Position below the icon tooltip.style.left = `${tooltipIcon.getBoundingClientRect().left + window.scrollX}px`; // Inject the static tooltip content with dynamic value in the tooltip let dynamicValue; switch (item.id) { case 'PERCY_A': dynamicValue = opponents.percy; dynamicValue = Math.round(dynamicValue * 10.0) / 10.0; break; case 'ROCKEFELLER_A': dynamicValue = opponents.rockefeller; dynamicValue = Math.round(dynamicValue * 10.0) / 10.0; break; case 'GOLDWATER_A': dynamicValue = opponents.goldwater; dynamicValue = Math.round(dynamicValue * 10.0) / 10.0; break; case 'AGNEW_A': dynamicValue = opponents.agnew; dynamicValue = Math.round(dynamicValue * 10.0) / 10.0; break; case 'LINDSAY_A': dynamicValue = opponents.lindsay; dynamicValue = Math.round(dynamicValue * 10.0) / 10.0; break; case 'REAGAN_A': dynamicValue = opponents.reagan; dynamicValue = Math.round(dynamicValue * 10.0) / 10.0; break; case 'NIXON_A': dynamicValue = opponents.nixon; dynamicValue = Math.round(dynamicValue * 10.0) / 10.0; break; case 'YORTY_A': dynamicValue = opponents.yorty; dynamicValue = Math.round(dynamicValue * 10.0) / 10.0; break; case 'HUGHES_A': dynamicValue = opponents.hughes; dynamicValue = Math.round(dynamicValue * 10.0) / 10.0; break; default: dynamicValue = 'N/A'; } tooltip.innerHTML = `${item.tooltip}

Position: ${dynamicValue}`; // Append the tooltip to the body document.body.appendChild(tooltip); // Remove the tooltip on mouse out tooltipIcon.addEventListener('mouseout', () => { document.body.removeChild(tooltip); }); }); // Add the tooltipIcon to the menuItem menuItem.appendChild(tooltipIcon); } menuListB.appendChild(menuItem); }); popOutMenu.appendChild(menuListB); const closeButton = document.createElement('button'); closeButton.innerText = 'Close'; closeButton.onclick = closeSurrogates; popOutMenu.appendChild(closeButton); document.body.appendChild(popOutMenu); makeDraggable(popOutMenu); } if (savedX !== null && savedY !== null) { popOutMenu.style.left = savedX + 'px'; popOutMenu.style.top = savedY + 'px'; } else { const buttonRect = event.target.getBoundingClientRect(); popOutMenu.style.left = buttonRect.right + 353 + 'px'; // Offset X popOutMenu.style.top = buttonRect.top - 292 + 'px'; // Offset Y savedX = popOutMenu.getBoundingClientRect().left; savedY = popOutMenu.getBoundingClientRect().top; } // Display the menu popOutMenu.style.display = 'block'; } function closeSurrogates() { const popOutMenu = document.getElementById('popOutMenu'); if (popOutMenu) { savedX = popOutMenu.getBoundingClientRect().left; savedY = popOutMenu.getBoundingClientRect().top; popOutMenu.remove(); } } function refreshSurrogates() { const popOutMenu = document.getElementById('popOutMenu'); if (popOutMenu) { popOutMenu.remove(); openSurrogates(); } } function makeDraggable(elmnt) { let pos1 = 0, pos2 = 0, pos3 = 0, pos4 = 0; elmnt.addEventListener('mousedown', dragMouseDown); function dragMouseDown(o) { if (["SELECT", "INPUT", "TEXTAREA"].includes(o.target.tagName)) return; o.preventDefault(); pos3 = o.clientX; pos4 = o.clientY; document.addEventListener('mousemove', elementDrag); document.addEventListener('mouseup', closeDragElement); document.body.style.userSelect = "none"; } function elementDrag(o) { o.preventDefault(); pos1 = pos3 - o.clientX; pos2 = pos4 - o.clientY; pos3 = o.clientX; pos4 = o.clientY; elmnt.style.top = (elmnt.offsetTop - pos2) + "px"; elmnt.style.left = (elmnt.offsetLeft - pos1) + "px"; } function closeDragElement() { document.removeEventListener('mousemove', elementDrag); document.removeEventListener('mouseup', closeDragElement); document.body.style.userSelect = "auto"; } } e.initDC = false construct = (a = 1) => { e.page = e.page + a < e.pages.length ? e.page + a : 0 let html = e.header; " for (i in e.executable) { if (e.executable[i][0] == e.page) { e.executable[i][1](); } } if (e.image == true) setTimeout(()=>{ candImg = $(".person_image")[0] if (candImg) { candImg.remove() $("#final_results_description")[0].style = ` text-align:left; margin-right: auto; ` console.log("RESULTS UPDATED"); $(".person_image").first().after(`${buttons}`); } }, 10) if(CONTINGENT == 0){ buttons = "" } return html; } changeTurnout = (multiplier = 1.0, stateID = 0) => { if (stateID != 0) { // If you've set a specific state, focus there. e.states_json[e.states_json.map(f=>f.pk).indexOf(stateID)].fields.popular_votes *= multiplier } else { // Otherwise, just target every state. e.states_json.forEach((a, i, arr) => { arr[i].fields.popular_votes *= multiplier; }); } } function coalitionTalks(results, optionalMode = false){ const electionResult = results; totalSeats = electionResult.reduce((sum, party) => sum + party.electoral_votes, 0); function hasMajority(coalition) { const coalitionSeats = coalition.parties.reduce((sum, partyId) => sum + electionResult.find(p => p.candidate === partyId).electoral_votes, 0); return coalitionSeats > (totalSeats / 2); } function getCoalitionsBySeatsRange(start, end) { const coalitionsBySeatsRange = []; return coalitionsBySeatsRange; } function getMajorityCoalitions() { return getCoalitionsBySeatsRange(0.1, Infinity); } function removeImpossibleCoalitions(coalitionList) { const possibleCoalitionsFunc = coalitionList.filter(coalition => { const impossibleCoalitions = coalition.impossibleCoalitions; return !coalitionList.some(c => c !== coalition && c.impossibleCoalitions.includes(coalition.id)); }); return possibleCoalitionsFunc; } if (optionalMode) { const coalitionsSet1 = getCoalitionsBySeatsRange(10, Infinity); // 10 or more seats above majority const coalitionsSet2 = getCoalitionsBySeatsRange(-10, 9); // Between 10 seats below and 10 seats above majority const coalitionsSet3 = getCoalitionsBySeatsRange(-30, -11); // More than 10 but less than 30 seats below majority return { coalitionsSet1, coalitionsSet2, coalitionsSet3 }; } else { const majorityCoalitions = getMajorityCoalitions(); const possibleCoalitionsFunc = removeImpossibleCoalitions(majorityCoalitions); return possibleCoalitionsFunc; } } var txtsaver = "" endingConstructor = (a = 1) => { if(resetPage){ a = 0; mapFooter.style.position = "relative"; mapFooter.style.display = "block"; $("#final_results_description")[0].innerHTML = construct(a); $("#endingtxt")[0].appendChild(difficultyTxt); $("#endingtxt")[0].appendChild(overallVote); $("#endingtxt")[0].appendChild(mapFooter); } endingPicker = (out, totv, aa, quickstats) => { if(CONTINGENT != null){ if(checkbox.checked || checkboxB.checked || checkboxC.checked){ endingPickerCONT(); return construct(0); } } if (!e.initDC) { e.initDC = true // adjustment magic to guarantee the correct ranking // adjustSeatAllocation(campaignTrail_temp, missedCandidates); possibleCoalitions = coalitionTalks(e.final_overall_results); //all coalitions with the winning party have their weight multiplied by this value let likelihood = 0; if((aa[0].electoral_votes == quickstats[0]) && (aa[0].popular_votes >= aa[1].popular_votes)){ likelihood += 3 } let likelihoodB = 0; if(republican == "lindsay" || republican == "rockefeller" || republican == "percy"){ likelihoodB += 1 } if(aa[0].electoral_votes == quickstats[0]){ likelihoodB += 1 } if(runningmatefullname == "Robert Byrd"){ likelihoodB = 2 } if(runningmatefullname == "Russell Long" && republican == "lindsay" && aa[0].electoral_votes == quickstats[0] && bumpkin == "Wallace"){ likelihoodB = -1 } let likelihoodC = 0; } e.pages = [] e.header = ""; e.executable = [] orderID = [aa[0].candidate, aa[1].candidate, aa[2].candidate, aa[3].candidate]; var playerEV = quickstats[0]; nct_stuff.themes[nct_stuff.selectedTheme].text_col = "white" // Slide 1 if(quickstats[0] > 269){ RFKwon = 1 } if (shot == 1) { // RFK's Torment if(!e.player_answers.includes(15672)){ e.pages.push(`

Apex

It was unbearable. The phone calls. The press reports. The unwarranted adulation. For weeks, Bobby had tried to block it all out. He had burrowed himself deep within his office, to focus on the issues and policies instead of the assassination attempt and the hollow victory that assassination attempt had brought him. He had tried to make monotony reassert itself, to make life move forward, but the world around him seemed trapped by it, transfixed.

Videos of his near-death played over and over on the nightly news. People dissected the image, analyzing each frame. It was all as he had imagined it—except he was still here.

Why was he still here? If he died, there at least would be something to commemorate. He would have sacrificed something. His presidency would have meant something. What had he done to deserve any of this?

He sat at the Resolute Desk with his head in his hands. He listened as the telephone rang once, twice, three times. There was a soft click and then his answering machine began playing.

“Mr. President, this is Gerald Ford. I was just checking in to see how you’re doing,” said the voice. “All of us here on the Hill are shaken, but we hope you are doing right by yourself. Take care and, uh, happy birthday.”

There was a click of the receiver. Then, again the ringing. Another voice.

“Mr. President, it’s Hale Boggs. Country’s gone to hell in a handbasket, hasn’t it? But at least you got a solid victory out of it. Something for people to remember for your birthday.” A pause. “Anyways, let me know if your people want me to help out at all next term. I think there’s a real appetite for bipartisanship.”

The phone clanged a third time. The president rose to his feet and stared at the machine.

“Mr. President, this is Earl Warren. Your brother’s death was an event that touched the heart of our nation. I, uh, hope that this event can be the vehicle to—.”

He did not hear the rest of the message. The president had grabbed the answering machine in both hands. He raised it above his head, tearing chords and snapping wires, and threw it hard across the room. There was an unpleasant noise as it embedded itself into the wall near Jack’s portrait and then hit the floor. A spiderweb of cracks remained where it had impacted.

It was pointless. It was all so pointless. All these fights. All this misery. He had wasted two years in this office twiddling his thumbs and now, suddenly, they wanted to hold hands and sing songs. His popularity has skyrocketed, not because of anything he had done, no. He hadn’t saved anyone. His support had skyrocketed because of what had happened to him, what he represented.

What was it all for? He stared up at the enormous portrait of his brother, silently pleading for some answer. What was he supposed to do?

There was no answer. He turned away. He folded his arms over his head and crumpled. Was this how Lyndon felt? Had he been consumed by the same knowledge that none of his victories would ever be his own, that he would always exist in the shadow of what had happened?

He could still remember getting the call from his brother Ted, two days after his birthday. He had been staring at the mass of cheery birthday cards in his garbage bin as his brother wept through the phone, “I’m so sorry. Robert, I’m so sorry. In Dallas. They say in Dallas he was—. Oh Robert. Bobby. Oh, Bobby. I’m sorry he’s—.”

“Surprise!”

He was aware of a change in the barometric pressure, but he did not move. His office was no longer his office. He was no longer alone. Eyes were on him. His movements were being studied. He was aware of all of this.

He unfolded himself and stared at his surroundings. A plywood desk in place of the Resolute Desk. A worn roller chair where his high-backed seat should be. A papery American flag and a printed portrait of his brother, eyes cast downward. It was cheap. Tacky.

Assembled before these set pieces were a handful of figures. Ethel. Moynihan. Unruh. Shriver. Byrd. Connally. Long. McNamara. His wife held a cake while the others stood unnaturally before him. They looked like ghosts.

“Well, Mr. President, let it never be said that you don’t know how to give a country a lot of bang for their buck,” said Byrd. “The way I see it, that image is gonna motivate all kinds of bills. I’ll work with Republicans to get legislation on things you aren’t even prepared for.”

“Right now, I’m at the Naval Observatory,” said Long quietly. “I’m watching it again and again. I’ll talk to people about it my whole life, how I coulda been president. It’s a great story.”

“I can see it too!” said Shriver. “And it’s exactly the kind of thing the family needs to keep its image alive! Documentary specials. Late-night interviews. Commemorative stamps...”

“I see it as an excuse for what we do and do not do in Vietnam,” said McNamara.

“I see it as a way to make sure the wrong kinds of criminals don’t get a piece of the pie,” said Moynihan.

“What I see is a great way to squeeze money out of our donors. Right now, I’m at a fundraiser, getting people to open their wallets by sobbing about what happened in Dallas. God bless America,” said Connally.

The president stood up shakily. “And what about them?” He said, pointing a finger past them, toward the teeming figures watching them out there in the dark. “What do they see?”

“A symbol. An icon. A brand. A representation of something that never was,” said Moynihan. “An empty vessel, endlessly repurposed.”

The president said nothing. He stared at the crowd, at the audience that stretched endlessly outward. It no longer mattered what he said. None of it would be remembered or respected. He was a puppet, a play-thing for children. His body would be used by forces larger than himself for things he neither cared about or understood. He had finally become exactly what his brother was. A story.

“Bobby,” his wife cleared his throat. She lifted the cake in a playful gesture, though her expression was one of defeat. “It’s time to blow out your candles.”

“Try not to blow it this time,” said Long.

“Close your eyes.”

“Hope for something better.”

“Try to make it a good one.”

There was wetness on his cheeks. He wiped it away and then, seeing no other option, he blew.

`) e.executable.push([0, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/9PAcuMl.png'})]) } else{ // Hughes + Shot e.pages.push(`

End

Robert Kennedy’s world had burst open like a blister. Inside was nothing but blood, pus, and exposed gore. It oozed from every television station—fixated on footage of his near-death—and from the newspapers—which talked salaciously about the unprecedented sham that had been the Howard Hughes campaign. It was all a joke to them. A silly, stupid joke. His suffering, his pain, it had all meant nothing. Everything he worked for—all for nothing.

This was not a nation that cared about Vietnam or the economy or even the state of its cities. This was a nation of children, hopped-up on cheap, dollar-store messiahs and stories of a past that never existed. They huffed hagiography from paper bags and let themselves imagine dark visions of violence, of death, of martyrdom, of Christians burned alive within golden bulls. All they cared about were leaders who looked good and delivered quips and got laid and were doomed by fate.

Which is of course why they had elected him. A failure. A man who had never delivered anything, who spent four years doing nothing but pose Christ-like beneath pictures of Jesus, who couldn’t even beat a real Republican candidate.

All he could see in his mind was Dallas. The man with the gun, approaching him in the crowd.

All he could see was Jack’s motorcade floating down Dealey Plaza.

The gun. The gun. The gun. He could see the gun. He could see the gun pointed at him and Jack and they were all the same. They were nothing. They were nothing except the Assassination. They would never be anything except the violence that stalked them. Their only legacy was the ruin and death they left in their wake. That is the only thing people saw in them. That was their only appeal.

He couldn’t bear it anymore. He couldn’t bear their poisonous, honeyed words. Not now. Not on his birthday.

His answering machine lay broken on the floor of the Oval Office. Long reams of tape bunched over the presidential seal. Chips and fragments of gears lay around it, alongside toppled pieces of furniture and shredded birthday cards. The fragments of happy, dull-eyed faces stared up at him as he poured himself a drink with a shaking hand. He brought the dark beverage to his lips, half-spilling it over his stained shirt. He had never been a drinker, but now…

He didn’t know what he was. All he knew was that he couldn’t escape. He would never escape. The glass dropped from his hands. He went to his knees to find it and, when he looked up, he was face to face with his brother’s portrait. Arms crossed. Eyes cast downward.

“Jack…” He whispered. “Please…”

The portrait said nothing. He shuffled forward, ignoring the pain as shattered glass and ruined equipment jabbed themselves into his knees.

“What was it all for?” He felt stupid. Childish. Great tears welled in his eyes. “Please tell me. Tell me what it was—.”

A spotlight turned on overhead.

“Oh, Bobby,” came a long, dark voice from somewhere behind him. Byrd’s voice.

He did not turn. He did not dare. He was aware that the carpet of his office had vanished and he was now kneeling on the hard, wood floor of a stage. The toppled pieces of furniture had become abstractions of themselves, shadows of the real objects. Props. Ghosts leered at him from across some great void.

He felt afraid.

“That’s no way to treat yourself. You’re an icon. A symbol,” a second voice had appeared from the void. It sounded like Connally, but it was not. It creeped toward him. “No one wants to worship a symbol that weeps girlishly on the floor. They want something more masculine. Reserved.”

“Think of Jack. Think of all the wonderful buildings named after him. That’s a legacy, isn’t it?” Another imposter cooed. It sounded like Moynihan but wrong. “You’ll be used forever.”

“An empire of images in your honor. Movies. Documentaries. Stage shows. Morbid obsessions. Dramatic recreations. Not every patriotic American boy gets to say the same. All they get is an flag and some shiny medals that get buried with them.” McNamara. Hot breath on his ear. Bobby shuddered. He closed his eyes and felt tears. “We know that better than most, don’t we?”

Something new shuffled across the stage. Its breathing was ragged. Joints cracked and popped. It spoke in a wispy voice that Bobby had only ever heard over the phone.

“I am watching a story. It is a story that will never leave us. Its power emerges from how simple it is. How it leaves out all the commitments and complications.”

The husk had reached him. Hands traced along his back, upward toward his neck.

“It is a story of a man who left no policies and created no institutions. It is a story of a man whose sole legacy is his image. It is an image that will allow his successors to limit civil liberties. It is an image that will be manipulated to deprive children of vaccines and send the poor to the gutter. It is an image that will be used to motivate men to kill and die for a country that cannot even be bothered to remember the names of the people they are at war with. It is an image that will be used repeatedly in all types of ways.”

Something slid across the floor. He opened his eyes to see, with horror, a cake lit with candles. Heat radiated from it, burning him. This would be his life forever.

“Happy birthday, Bobby.”

Bobby Kennedy opened his mouth. Then he began to scream.

Termination

Robert F. Kennedy was past feeling. Calls came and went to his office. He stumbled through the post-election ceremonies. He was aware of the cameras trained closely on his face and the people shouting his name. Mostly, though, he felt numb. After all his time in Office, after all his waiting and yearning, he had not expected this as an outcome. Not seriously, at least. And yet…

Briefings piled on his desk about Vietnam, about the economy, about the unrest in cities. Weeks passed. None of his aides said anything, but it was clear he had yet to touch any of them. Nothing felt real. Nothing made sense. Even as he rolled into November 20th—his birthday—it all seemed impossible.

He stood at the window, a glass of bourbon in his hand. On his desk sat his answering machine. After a swell of well-wishers, a message played that he had not expected. A message from his predecessor, Lyndon Johnson.

“Bobby…” The old man’s voice was hoarse and ragged. In his mind’s eye, Bobby could see the old man in the living room of his ranch—his hair grown long, his shirt untucked, fat. “I wanted to call you. I should have called sooner, but…” There was a series of phlegm-filled coughs. “Oh goddamnit, I’ve never been good at these fucking things. It just seemed like now would be a good time, what with the Election.”

Bobby continued to stare at the window. His expression was unreadable.

“I’m not sure why things ended up with us like they did. Maybe it was McCarthy.” Kennedy imagined his fallen, one-time hero—Joseph McCarthy. “Maybe it was the hunting trip.” He saw himself sprawled flat on his back from the recoil of a gun as Lyndon laughed above him. “I don’t know. I wish I knew why you hated me. Hell, I wish I knew why I hated you. Seems like a damn silly thing now.”

In the reflection of the window, he could make out the faint shape of his brother’s portrait. Suddenly, the sight of it was unbearable. He stared down into the dark brown liquid of his drink.

“I want you to know that I don’t blame you for what happened. Lord knows I tried to do my best but—.” More coughing, this time even more ragged. “There’s no reason we gotta be at each other’s throats. Not anymore, at least.”

Bobby swished the liquid in his glass, feeling something hard form in his throat.

“I’d like to hear from you sometime. No press. No recorders. No fucking cameras. I’d just like to…” A sigh. “Move on. Have us talk like men.”

There was an achingly long pause.

“I’ll understand if you don’t respond, but your people know where to reach me.”

There was the sound of movement. Bobby imagined Johnson leaning back into his easy chair, staring out a window at the same sky from miles away.

“So long, Bobby. Happy birthday. Send Ethel my love.”

There was a clang of a phone being set on its receiver, followed by a whirring. When the device reached the end of the tape, there was a click followed by silence. He closed his eyes.

“You mean all this time we coulda been friends,” said a loud voice in a high-pitched, mocking whine. “What a joke.”

The noise shocked him into action. Robert swung around, nearly spilling his drink, and gasped. His office was no longer his office. It looked like a cheap imitation of it. A chipped, wooden desk in place of his own. A paper American flag that hung loosely on a pole. A printed picture of his brother. Then, in place of the back wall of the Oval Office, a yawning void. Across the gap, he could see a thousand dark figures, watching him closely.

“You’d think a man like Lyndon would know better. I mean, really… It’s sad.”

Bobby turned his gaze away from the spectral figures in the darkness to the far side of the stage. Entering from the left was the squat figure of Robert Byrd. He looked strange, surreal. Stage make-up was plastered over his face and, in his right hand, he balanced a single cake. The words, “Happy Birthday, Bobby!” were written in frosting across it.

Bobby opened and shut his mouth uselessly. It seemed like an eternity before his voice returned to him.

“I don’t think it’s pathetic at all…”

Byrd clicked his tongue. He sauntered across the stage and set the cake on his desk. Its candles blazed. “Don’t be stupid, Bobby. It’s too late for any of that.”

“But it’s not. He just said—.”

“The two of you are moving in two completely different directions. He’s Joan Crawford, dying on the beach and you… you…” He threw his hands up. A smile spread across his face. “Oh, Bobby. Oh my dear Bobby. They’re never gonna forget you now. Not ever. You belong to the ages.”

Bobby balled his fists and walked around the desk to face the intruder. He had a half an inch on Byrd and he tried to make that difference notable. “The hell do you mean? I didn’t do any of this to be some… some… marionette. A play-thing for you or the historians or anyone—.”

“You really believe that?” Byrd shouted. He pressed a fat finger into Robert’s chest. “You coulda passed bills. You coulda fought for your people. You coulda tried to do everything you promised in ‘68. You chose not to. You chose to create this impossible, absurd outcome. The only way you coulda done it is if you aimed for it.”

Bobby said nothing. He jutted out his jaw. A sly grin returned to Byrd’s face.

“You gave up the impossible dream cause you wanted to be remembered,” Byrd said. “Just like your brother.”

Bobby stared at him. The two of them locked eyes. Bobby tightened his fists. Then, when the pressure had become unbearable, he looked away. Byrd clapped with delight and rounded behind the president. Bobby felt a strong hand on his back.

“Now don’t be too sour, my dear Bobby. It’s not all bad. They’ll use you forever. Your face. Your name. It will be inescapable. The first and last word in politics. It’ll be Bobby Kennedy. Bobby Kennedy forever.”

Byrd led him toward his desk where the cake still sat. The candles had burned halfway down their wax. They were mesmerizing in the darkness.

“I should know. I’m gonna be an institution myself. Hell, I already am in West Virginia. They use my name for all kinds of shit.” The two were stationed in front of the cake now. A hard hand pushed him downward. “The two of us are the only people alive who understand the need for a show. And people are gonna love it.”

Bobby stared at the flames and the wax as it dripped downward.

“So go on, make a wish, Bobby. This is what you wanted, so make a wish that it all works out in the end, that they’ll use you for something good.”

Bobby breathed in.

“And, good God, try not to blow it.”

He blew out the candles. The stage lights went dark. They returned to the abyss.

Consummation

The White House was strangely quiet in the days after Bobby Kennedy’s victory over “Howard Hughes”. There were the usual statements to the press. Congratulatory letters arrived from abroad. His allies toasted to his success with speeches prepared weeks prior, speeches that made no acknowledgment of the calamitous end to the Election. Bobby Kennedy sat through all of these. He forced himself not to squirm. He tried to accept these kind words at face value. He spent long nights listening to the messages left on his Office phone.

It’s where he found himself weeks after the catastrophe, on November 20th, his birthday.

“Hello, Mr. President. Gerald Ford. I wanted to call on the occasion of your birthday to wish my best to you and your wife. I understand that it’s been some time since our last conversation, back when I was still in the House, but with the state my party is in—.””

He thumbed the skip button on his recorder before agitation could overwhelm him. Tape whirred in the machine.

“Mr. President. It’s Bob Dole. I was wondering if you had received my letter about pardons for uh… this Irving business. It’s clear that all of us got put in a bad spot, but it’s Irving and Morton’s fault as opposed to the whole lot. It would be magnanimous if—.”

He president let out an involuntary snarl. He jammed the machine harder. The tape rattled in the machine. There was the squeaking of gears before the next message played.

“Robert, this is, uh, Dick Nixon. Listen, this whole Hughes business is a terrible thing. For everyone. I am sure I’m the last person you want to hear from, but I wanted to talk to you about ways we could all come together. As a country.” There was a long pause on the machine. “Oh and, uh, Pat says happy birth—.”

He hit the machine so hard that something snapped within the machine. Gears grinded against one another. Black ribbon poured outward and an acrid smell filled his office. Robert walked around his desk and with a yank pulled the cord free from the wall. The grinding ceased and the room lapsed into silence.

He stood there, head down, chord in his hand. He felt on the verge of frenzy.

For two years, he had tried to prove himself. He had done everything right after the calamity of the midterms, had tried his hardest to salvage the Democratic Party from disrepute. Instead of an opponent, the Republican Party had sent him a scammer wearing the mask of a dying man. They had sent him Clifford Irving, who had offered no full-throated defense of conservatism but a collection of cheap tricks and gimmicks. Celebrity. Tabloid gossip.

This was supposed to be an Election to prove himself and show he could save the nation’s soul. Instead, he had gotten lucky opposing a huckster. He had become the victor of the lowest turnout election in American history.

He felt scammed as everyone else.

He dropped the cord and walked across the room to the painting of his brother Jack. Head down, arms crossed. For much of his presidency, he had looked at this portrait as a source of solace. Now, all he could focus on were the individual brush strokes. It too was not the real thing. Only an imitation. It had nothing of his brother’s real dimension. It knew nothing of his tragedies, of how he had spent the last few hours of his life.

He could still remember getting the call from his brother Ted, almost nine years ago. He had been staring at the mass of cheery birthday cards in his garbage bin as his brother wept through the phone, “I’m so sorry. Robert, I’m so sorry. In Dallas. They say in Dallas he was—. Oh Robert. Bobby. Oh, Bobby. I’m sorry he’s—.”

He was not alone in his Office.

Though he had not moved from his spot before the painting, he was aware of something shifting behind him. A figure sitting in the chair behind his desk. There was a groan of movement.

“I was a man once too, you know,” said the creature in a low, rattling voice. “I had a name. Then they took it away from me.”

Bobby said nothing. He kept his eyes fixed firmly on the painting. It felt as though someone had turned a bright spotlight over him. Sweat poured down his back.

“They did the same to your brother. They didn’t even wait until his body was cold. They use his image in ways he couldn’t even imagine.”

He remained frozen, even as his eyes searched around frantically for help. Instead he was greeted by more strangeness. His office no longer looked real. It looked cheap. Tacky. He could see the blurry outline of a paper American flag. Instead of his wall’s back office there was a yawning blackness from which a thousand watching people could be seen.

“They’ll do the same to you too.”

He could hear the figure rising. Its bones cracked and shifted. He wondered if he should run or scream but his voice had left him. He could only do one thing. The fake American flag fluttered at the edge of his sight.

“It’ll be sooner than you think. They’ll use you up until there’s nothing left. Then you’ll be another image on a wall, just like—.”

He grabbed the pole holding the flag and turned, yelling. He was aware of the crowd beyond his reach leaning forward. He raised the flag over his head, ready to strike and—.

There was no one there. A single small cake sat on his desk. Candles blazed. Forty-seven candles for forty-seven years. Written in icing on the top was a single phrase, “Happy birthday, Bobby.”

He took a nervous step toward his desk. The stage on which he was standing seemed deathly quiet. He set the flag pole down against the edge of the prop desk.

Make a wish, said a voice in his head, make it a good one.

Try not to blow it, said another.

His head swam. He leaned forward. He looked strange and sickly illuminated beneath the candle light.

Hope for something better.

Bobby stared into the candles. Then, before he could stop himself, he blew.

`) e.executable.push([0, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/ZJ8zpZJ.png'})]) } else if(e.player_answers.includes(9296) && !(e.player_answers.includes(8988)) && !(e.player_answers.includes(9709)) && runningmatefullname == "Russell Long" && vietnam == 4 && econCrash == 0){ e.pages.push(`

Accomplishment

Election Day came and went. It was followed by the usual pomp—celebratory newspaper headlines, congratulatory letters, phone calls from well-wishers. He did not, as he was so prone to do, retreat into himself. Instead, he tried to force himself to be courteous and engaged, to understand his supporters’ concerns, to treat them with real gratitude.

After all, his election had been far from assured. Over the last two years, he had bucked convention. He had taken the hard road. He had focused on delivering change—real change—at a time when it would have been easy to keep his head down and avoid hard, alienating decisions. Instead of abandoning his supporters for greater appeal, he had remained firmly committed to realizing the vision he promised in 1968.

Nothing was definitively solved—-briefings to continue to pour in about Vietnam, the sluggish economy, and unrest—-but he felt like he had a direction now. He was moving the country forward, and there was nothing his enemies could do but call to complain.

“Robert,” came a Southern growl through the answering machine on his desk.

It was November 20th, several weeks after the Election. He found himself seated in the Oval Office, trying to finish some paperwork before a birthday party in his honor, one that his wife had practically forced on him. He stopped thumbing through his inbox to listen.

“This is Robert Byrd. I don’t know what your people are telling you right now. I’m sure they’re spinning you some fanciful yarn about what to expect in the next four years, but if you think you can ignore the interests of your party and the South—.”

He pressed the button on his machine to skip the message. On his desk beside his inbox was a party hat, a gift left behind from one of his children.

“Mr. President,” the voice this time was thin, with a slight German accent. “It’s Henry Kissinger. I know you are used to getting your way, but I want to warn you to tread lightly. Vietnam is one thing, but this country will not tolerate the same unrestrained deference toward China and the Soviet Union. It is irresponsible statecraft to—.”

He pressed the skip button again. The machine whirred. He picked up the hat and played with it in his fingers.

“Bobby. It’s Moynihan. I want to be a team player, but I simply can’t stay silent any longer. What you’ve done with the Family Assistance Plan, it’s unconscionable. This thing cannot endure long-term as it stands. It’s rewarding laziness. You’ve completely corrupted—.”

He pressed STOP on the machine. The room lapsed back into silence. He stared at the small paper hat in his hands. He twisted it between his fingers, marveling at the striped pattern that snaked around it. What a strange thing, he thought. How strange to imagine that he was here, at the age of 47.

For so long, he had imagined himself being struck down before reaching this summit. He had darkly imagined his demise by a hail of bullets, by an ungrateful nation, by his own bigotries or cowardice. It would have been the perfect ending to his life, a dramatic final flourish, something to give meaning to all the pain and suffering he’d endured. And yet…

He set the hat down and stood up, turning to stare at the portrait of his brother on the wall. Its arms crossed, head cast downward in an expression of eternal sorrow. He had stared at this portrait so many times throughout his presidency. He had wondered if Jack would be proud of what he’d done and if he’d appreciate the sacrifices he had made in his name.

Now, however, he realized those were the wrong questions.

His vision began to shimmer. He wiped tears from his eyes and as he did, he realized that the portrait before him was no longer how he remembered it. Instead of oils, it had transformed into something printed. His desk had transformed into something of cardboard. His phone had become useless plastic. Less objects than a recreation of them. A memory. A haunting.

“Don’t stop now, Bobby,” came a voice from behind.

He turned. Situated before him was a small crowd of people. Ethel. Unruh. Shriver. Long. Loved ones. Friends and family. He stared at them, at the birthday cake in his wife’s outstretched hands, and then at what lay beyond them, stirring in the darkness.

“I loved him so much,” Robert said.

Shriver cast his eyes downward. “We know.”

“He was the world.”

“He was the world to all of us,” said Unruh, his eyes hidden behind his glasses.

“But he’s gone now and he’s never coming back,” his vision blurred again. “None of us ever get to come back again. Not as we were.”

“We become symbols. Abstractions,” said Long. “Our memory get abused by people who don’t understand who we were or what we stood for. Our flailings get reinvented as moments of great moral weight.”

“It was never about legacy,” the president muttered. “It was about living for the people who are alive now.”

“It’s about letting them in,” said Long.

“Opening the door,” said Shriver.

“Moving forward,” said Unruh.

“It’s about growing up,” said the president. He wiped his eyes against the back of shirt and gave a soft chuckle. “Damn, all of this, just to learn a lesson straight out of a fairy tale.”

He looked upward, aware of the crowd in the darkness but no longer caring. They could watch all they wanted, but what they saw wasn’t half as important as what he did. They had no claim over his soul.

“Alright,” he said at long last. “Should we get this party over with?”

His wife took a step toward him. She smiled and raised the cake upward. “Come on, Bobby. Blow out the candles and make a wish.”

“Don’t blow it obsessing on things that never were,” said Shriver.

“Hope that people use this to build something better,” said Unruh.

“Try to make this life a good one,” said Long.

The president stared into the candles. He thought of Jack one last time. Then he took a deep breath in, held it, and blew. And with that, at last, the stage lights dimmed and the curtain closed.

`) e.executable.push([0, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/UDIBLwk.png'})]) } else if(runningmatefullname == "Robert Byrd"){ e.pages.push(`

Coup de Grâce

After the celebrations, after the speeches, after the parades and congratulatory letters and buzzy press reports commemorating his decisive victory, Bobby found himself alone again. It had happened sooner than he’d imagined. The relief he’d felt on Election Day vanished beneath waves of briefings about the situation in Vietnam, about the struggling economy, about the unrest in cities. His victory had resolved nothing. There was no great swelling of music, no rolling of the credits. Instead, he found himself faced with another four years of intractable problems and unpleasant compromises.

He pushed his way down halls of the West Wing, grunting in response to the congratulations of well-wishers. He turned sharply at the door of the Oval Office and, before anyone else could interrupt his ruminations, he sealed himself inside. The room was dark. Quiet. On his desk blinked the single red light of his answering machine.

He stared at it, hairs creeping up along the back of his neck. Then, before he could stop himself, he jammed the button with his finger. There was the whirring of tape and, then, the sudden intrusion of voices.

“Mr. President, Senator Eastland calling,” came the grovelling voice from the machine. “My, uh, staff thought it useful to call you and, uh, send you congratulations on your victory and your birthday.” A long pause. “After seeing what you’ve done with Byrd, I feel I may have misjudged you. Have your people call my office and we can try to set something up.”

The president pursed his lips. He stiffly retrieved a bottle of whisky from a compartment behind his desk.

“Bobby, how the hellare you, you goddamn bastard,” slurred a voice through the machine. The light clinking of glass could be heard in the background. “It’s Herman Talmadge. Senator from… oh you know. Listen, I’m sure you’re out with your boys tonight, but I wanna make amends for the rough business we gave you in the Senate. You really turned things around. Showed the… crooks the business. You’re one of the good ones, Bob, don’t forget that.”

The bottle hit the desk, harder than the president intended. He gripped it tightly in his hand, unable to will himself to pour a glass.

“Robert. Robby. Bobby. Byrd told me he saw something in you but I didn’t believe it,” came the voice of Dolph Briscoe. “Maybe you Yankee boys know how to play ball after all. Listen, I got some meetings coming up with some of my buddies in Texas. I thought you and Byrd might—.”

Bobby tried to slam the messages off but his hand was still gripping the bottle. The glass collided with the machine, like a captain christening a ship. There was a crack. Then, it shattered. Liquid spread across his desk and papers, tricking down the sides of the desk. None of this stopped the voices, which continued to pour through the receiver into the room. One thousand Good Old Boys all wanting a piece of his time! One thousand Southerners all congratulating him for seeing their point of view! He was drowning in it.

He threw the leaking bottle into a garbage can then slammed the answering machine with his fist. The voices ruptured into silence.

Why was he so miserable? He stared intently at the dark pool on his desk. Why couldn’t he be happy at having won? At having won decisively. Historically. He’d worked hard, hadn’t he? He’d proven he wasn’t just a fluke, a punk kid with a shiny name.

Had Jack felt this way when he won all those years ago? Had he taken this office with all its power and prestige and realized just how little there was to it? Did he feel the same emptiness inside him? Or had his death been a relief? Had it saved him from the dirty business of having to contend with all these Southern interests and compromising on his principles? Had death saved him from the loss of his immortal soul at the hands of these horned devils?

He could still remember getting the call from his brother Ted, two days after his birthday. He had been staring at the mass of cheery birthday cards in his garbage bin as his brother wept through the phone, “I’m so sorry. Robert, I’m so sorry. In Dallas. They say in Dallas he was—. Oh Robert. Bobby. Oh, Bobby. I’m sorry he’s—.”

“Surprise!”

Lights blared to life overhead. The president felt himself involuntarily gasp. He could suddenly see through the artifice, through the cheapness of the scenery. A paper American flag. A chipped desk. A plastic red telephone. Jack’s portrait. Less objects than a recreation of them. A memory. A haunting.

And then, situated across from him, a mass of bodies. Ethel. Moynihan. Unruh. Shriver. Byrd. Connally. Long. McNamara. He stared uncomprehendingly at their smiling faces, at the cake in his wife’s outstretched arms, and then at what lay beyond them, stirring in the darkness beyond him.

“What—?”

“Oh happy birthday, Bobby!” said the crowd as one.

Bobby remained frozen beneath the spotlight. Gears moved in his head. “You’re not real, are you?”

There was a pause, like a gear sliding out of place, before the scene reasserted itself.

“Well, hell, what kind of question is that,” said Byrd. The chairman gave a fiendish chuckle. “Me? You? We’re as real as people decide we are.”

Long gave a sad, defeated smile. “ And I don’t think anyone’s gonna forget anytime soon what you and Byrd accomplished together. All those votes, you must be happy.”

“A landslide victory,” said Unruh. The words fell out of his mouth like lead. “All you had to do was empower the very people you once stood again.”

“But still you have your victory, your place in history. Not even Jack could pull that one off,” said Shriver in a dull voice.

“Well, Jack could of. He coulda had a real nice victory before the civil rights business and that damn stupid thing with King. Talk about a crisis of conscience,” said Connally. He gave Byrd a leering smile. “But you know better, don’t you, Bobby?”

“There are always sacrifices that have to be made, people to be cast aside,” said McNamara, red tie like a gash across his neck.

“For the greater good,” said Long. “Isn’t that what you always say?”

Bobby backed away from the assembled group and the teeming shapes in the darkness. “No. That’s not what happened. I… I… made compromises, but I won this to prove… I won this for…”

“Oh, yes, for the party. For the family. For Jack. We know. We understand,” said Connally with exaggerated deference. “What a wonderful little story to tell. It’s just the kind of thing people will remember. We are nothing without our stories, aren’t we?”

“God, imagine the stories they’ll tell about me?” Said Byrd, half to Bobby and half to the crowd. “I imagine I’ll be able to sit nice and pretty with that one for a good long while. Just gotta wait for that egg to hatch.”

There was a cackle somewhere in the dark beyond the scene. Bobby’s head turned toward the noise, toward the rows of bodies beyond his reach, rows that seemed to stretch infinitely outward.

“No. I didn’t do this just to be remembered as a personality,” he wasn’t sure who he was pleading to anymore. “It was never about that. It was never about becoming president for the sake of being president. It was about opening up possibilities. It was about helping people expand their possibilities, to think about…”

“Things that never were.” It was Ethel’s voice this time. He stared at her, his wife, still holding a cake whose candles were half-melted. She had a strange, sad expression.

“Surely, people remember the policies we put in place,” Bobby whispered.

“Robert,” his wife said. She took a step closer.

“They remember the institutions we built.”

“Robby,” she said, closer now. Her voice was barely more than a whisper.

“The people we helped.”

“Bobby.”

She was right on top of him now. Her face looked eerie beneath the lit candles.

“What was it all for? Was all this pain just to be… preserved as just another face on a wall? To be made like…?” He gestured uselessly to the false portrait of Jack.

“Come on, Bobby. Blow out the candles and make a wish,” said his wife.

“Try not to blow it this time,” said Long.

“Close your eyes.”

“Hope for something better.”

“Try to make it a good one.”

There was nowhere else to go. Nothing else to do. He gave one last look across the stage and then to the crowd judging him from beyond. Then, he shut his eyes, took a deep breath, and blew.
