Grand Finale

After the celebrations, after the speeches, after the parades and congratulatory letters and buzzy press reports commemorating his decisive victory, Bobby found himself alone again. It had happened sooner than he’d imagined. The relief he’d felt on Election Day vanished beneath waves of briefings about the situation in Vietnam, about the struggling economy, about the unrest in cities. His victory had resolved nothing. There was no great swelling of music, no rolling of the credits. Instead, he found himself faced with another four years of intractable problems and unpleasant compromises.

He pushed his way down halls of the West Wing, grunting in response to the congratulations of well-wishers. He turned sharply at the door of the Oval Office and, before anyone else could interrupt his ruminations, he sealed himself inside. The room was dark. Quiet. On his desk blinked the single red light of his answering machine.

He stared at it, hairs creeping up along the back of his neck. Then, before he could stop himself, he jammed the button with his finger. There was the whirring of tape and, then, the sudden intrusion of voices.

“Heya Robby! It’s Johnny Carson!” came the voice from the machine. “All of us at NBC wanted to wish you a happy birthday and congratulate you again on your victory. Looks like the Kennedy brand is still intact. Let us know if you ever want to come on the show. We’d all be very interested in hearing what you’re up to.”

The president’s face remained stony. He stiffly retrieved a bottle of whisky from a compartment behind his desk.

“Robbo, it’s Armand Hammer! Occidental Petroleum! I called your secretary to see if you had any plans for your birthday tonight, but she says you’re busy. Well, I guess I’ll have to find some other time to suck up to the Commander-in-Chief.” He let off a fake laugh. “Just a joke. Let me know when I can take you out. We can really help each other out, you and I.”

The bottle hit the desk with a clunk. He gripped it tightly in his hand, unable to will himself to pour a glass.

“Robert, it’s Jackie. Oh...I’m so very sorry that I won’t be able to make it, but I'm calling from Skorpios, and Aristotle and I wanted to wish—.”

Bobby tried to slam the messages off but his hand was still gripping the bottle. The glass collided with the machine, like a captain christening a ship. There was a crack. Then, the sight of liquid spreading across his desk and papers, tricking down the sides of the desk. None of this stopped the voices, which continued to pour through the receiver into the room. One thousand people all wanting a piece of his time! One thousand people all wanting his glory! He was drowning in it.

He threw the leaking bottle into a garbage can then slammed the answering machine with his fist. The voices ruptured into silence.

Why was he so miserable? He stared intently at the dark pool on his desk. Why couldn’t he be happy at having won? At having won decisively. Historically. He’d worked hard, hadn’t he? He’d proven he wasn’t just a fluke, a punk kid with a shiny name.

Had Jack felt this way when he won all those years ago? Had he taken this office with all its power and prestige and realized just how little there was to it? Did he feel the same emptiness inside him? Was he aware that all his victory would amount to was a picture in a history book? That all the compromises he had made had closed off the futures he once dreamed of? That none of those compromises would even matter because in less than four years, he’d be dead?

He could still remember getting the call from his brother Ted, two days after his birthday. He had been staring at the mass of cheery birthday cards in his garbage bin as his brother wept through the phone, “I’m so sorry. Robert, I’m so sorry. In Dallas. They say in Dallas he was—. Oh Robert. Bobby. Oh, Bobby. I’m sorry he’s—.”

“Surprise!”

Lights blared to life overhead. The president felt himself involuntarily gasp. He could suddenly see through the artifice, through the cheapness of the scenery. A paper American flag. A chipped desk. A plastic red telephone. Jack’s portrait. Less objects than a recreation of them. A memory. A haunting.

And then, situated across from him, a mass of bodies. Ethel. Moynihan. Unruh. Shriver. Byrd. Connally. Long. McNamara. He stared uncomprehendingly at their smiling faces, at the cake in his wife’s outstretched arms, and then at what lay beyond them, stirring in the darkness beyond him.

“What—?”

“Oh happy birthday, Bobby!” said the crowd as one.

Bobby remained frozen beneath the spotlight. Gears moved in his head. “You’re not real, are you?”

There was a pause, like a gear sliding out of place, before the scene reasserted itself.

“What is?” said Unruh, straightening his thin black tie. “Me? You? We’re as real as people decide we are.”

“And the people have decided that you are as real as they get, Bobby dearest. A landslide victory—oh my goodness,” intoned Byrd. “It don’t get any more real than that.”

“Not even Jack could pull that one off,” said Shriver, cheerily.

“Well, he could of, before the civil rights business and did that damn stupid thing with King. Talk about a crisis of conscience,” said Connally. He gave a leering smile. “But you know better, don’t you, Bobby?”

“There are always sacrifices that have to be made, people to be cast aside,” said McNamara, red tie like a gash across his neck.

“For the greater good,” said Long.

Bobby backed away from the assembled group and the teeming shapes in the darkness. “No. That’s not what happened. I… I… made compromises, but I won this to prove… I won this for…”

“Oh, yes, for the party. For the family. For Jack. We know. We understand,” said Connally with exaggerated deference. “What a wonderful little story to tell. It’s just the kind of thing people will remember. We are nothing without our stories, aren’t we?”

There was a cackle somewhere in the dark beyond the scene. Bobby’s head turned toward the noise, toward the rows of bodies beyond his reach, rows that seemed to stretch infinitely outward.

“No. I didn’t do this just to be remembered as a personality,” he wasn’t sure who he was pleading to anymore. “It was never about that. It was never about becoming president for the sake of being president. It was about opening up possibilities. It was about helping people expand their possibilities, to think about…”

“Things that never were.” It was Ethel’s voice this time. He stared at her, his wife, still holding a cake whose candles were half-melted. She had a strange, sad expression.

“Surely, people remember the policies we put in place,” Bobby whispered.

“Robert,” his wife said. She took a step closer.

“They remember the institutions we built.”

“Robby,” she said, closer now. Her voice was barely more than a whisper.

“The people we helped.”

“Bobby.”

She was right on top of him now. Her face looked eerie beneath the lit candles.

“What was it all for? Was all this pain just to be… preserved as just another face on a wall? To be made like…?” He gestured uselessly to the false portrait of Jack.

“Come on, Bobby. Blow out the candles and make a wish,” said his wife.

“Try not to blow it this time,” said Long.

“Close your eyes.”

“Hope for something better.”

“Try to make it a good one.”

There was nowhere else to go. Nothing else to do. He gave one last look across the stage and then to the crowd judging him from beyond. Then, he shut his eyes, took a deep breath, and blew.

Accomplishment

Election Day came and went. It was followed by the usual pomp—celebratory newspaper headlines, congratulatory letters, phone calls from well-wishers. He did not, as he was so prone to do, retreat into himself. Instead, he tried to force himself to be courteous and engaged, to understand his supporters’ concerns, to treat them with real gratitude.

After all, his election had been far from assured. Over the last two years, he had bucked convention. He had taken the hard road. He had focused on delivering change—real change—at a time when it would have been easy to keep his head down and avoid hard, alienating decisions. Instead of abandoning his supporters for greater appeal, he had remained firmly committed to realizing the vision he promised in 1968.

Nothing was definitively solved—-briefings to continue to pour in about Vietnam, the sluggish economy, and unrest—-but he felt like he had a direction now. He was moving the country forward, and there was nothing his enemies could do but call to complain.

“Robert,” came a Southern growl through the answering machine on his desk.

It was November 20th, several weeks after the Election. He found himself seated in the Oval Office, trying to finish some paperwork before a birthday party in his honor, one that his wife had practically forced on him. He stopped thumbing through his inbox to listen.

“This is Robert Byrd. I don’t know what your people are telling you right now. I’m sure they’re spinning you some fanciful yarn about what to expect in the next four years, but if you think you can ignore the interests of your party and the South—.”

He pressed the button on his machine to skip the message. On his desk beside his inbox was a party hat, a gift left behind from one of his children.

“Mr. President,” the voice this time was thin, with a slight German accent. “It’s Henry Kissinger. I know you are used to getting your way, but I want to warn you to tread lightly. Vietnam is one thing, but this country will not tolerate the same unrestrained deference toward China and the Soviet Union. It is irresponsible statecraft to—.”

He pressed the skip button again. The machine whirred. He picked up the hat and played with it in his fingers.

“Bobby. It’s Moynihan. I want to be a team player, but I simply can’t stay silent any longer. What you’ve done with the Family Assistance Plan, it’s unconscionable. This thing cannot endure long-term as it stands. It’s rewarding laziness. You’ve completely corrupted—.”

He pressed STOP on the machine. The room lapsed back into silence. He stared at the small paper hat in his hands. He twisted it between his fingers, marveling at the striped pattern that snaked around it. What a strange thing, he thought. How strange to imagine that he was here, at the age of 47.

For so long, he had imagined himself being struck down before reaching this summit. He had darkly imagined his demise by a hail of bullets, by an ungrateful nation, by his own bigotries or cowardice. It would have been the perfect ending to his life, a dramatic final flourish, something to give meaning to all the pain and suffering he’d endured. And yet…

He set the hat down and stood up, turning to stare at the portrait of his brother on the wall. Its arms crossed, head cast downward in an expression of eternal sorrow. He had stared at this portrait so many times throughout his presidency. He had wondered if Jack would be proud of what he’d done and if he’d appreciate the sacrifices he had made in his name.

Now, however, he realized those were the wrong questions.

His vision began to shimmer. He wiped tears from his eyes and as he did, he realized that the portrait before him was no longer how he remembered it. Instead of oils, it had transformed into something printed. His desk had transformed into something of cardboard. His phone had become useless plastic. Less objects than a recreation of them. A memory. A haunting.

“Don’t stop now, Bobby,” came a voice from behind.

He turned. Situated before him was a small crowd of people. Ethel. Unruh. Shriver. Long. Loved ones. Friends and family. He stared at them, at the birthday cake in his wife’s outstretched hands, and then at what lay beyond them, stirring in the darkness.

“I loved him so much,” Robert said.

Shriver cast his eyes downward. “We know.”

“He was the world.”

“He was the world to all of us,” said Unruh, his eyes hidden behind his glasses.

“But he’s gone now and he’s never coming back,” his vision blurred again. “None of us ever get to come back again. Not as we were.”

“We become symbols. Abstractions,” said Long. “Our memory get abused by people who don’t understand who we were or what we stood for. Our flailings get reinvented as moments of great moral weight.”

“It was never about legacy,” the president muttered. “It was about living for the people who are alive now.”

“It’s about letting them in,” said Long.

“Opening the door,” said Shriver.

“Moving forward,” said Unruh.

“It’s about growing up,” said the president. He wiped his eyes against the back of shirt and gave a soft chuckle. “Damn, all of this, just to learn a lesson straight out of a fairy tale.”

He looked upward, aware of the crowd in the darkness but no longer caring. They could watch all they wanted, but what they saw wasn’t half as important as what he did. They had no claim over his soul.

“Alright,” he said at long last. “Should we get this party over with?”

His wife took a step toward him. She smiled and raised the cake upward. “Come on, Bobby. Blow out the candles and make a wish.”

“Don’t blow it obsessing on things that never were,” said Shriver.

“Hope that people use this to build something better,” said Unruh.

“Try to make this life a good one,” said Long.

The president stared into the candles. He thought of Jack one last time. Then he took a deep breath in, held it, and blew. And with that, at last, the stage lights dimmed and the curtain closed.

`) e.executable.push([0, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/UDIBLwk.png'})]) } else if(runningmatefullname == "Russell Long"){ e.pages.push(`

Finale

After the days of waiting, the exhausting recounts, the final declarations and rosy press reports spinning his narrow victory, Bobby found himself alone again. He found himself picking confetti out of his suit and returning to his quiet office. He found days melt into weeks and a monotony reassert itself over the White House. Briefings came—about the situation in Vietnam, about the struggling economy, about unrest in the cities. The jubilation of Election Night vanished into memory and here, still, he remained. Older but not wiser.

With a brush of his hand, the president clicked the answering machine on his desk. He stood in the dark and waited. There was the whirring of tape and, then, the sudden intrusion of voices.

“Heya, Bobby! This is your sister Eunice! I’m afraid I’m out of the country so I’ll miss your birthday celebrations, but I wanted to give you my best anyways. Forty-seven! It’s hard to believe! Try to take care of yourself, would you?”

Bobby shook his head and retrieved a bottle of whisky from a compartment behind his desk.

“Hi Robert, it’s Nick. Nick Arundel. I, uh, figured that your victory party two weeks ago was better than any present I could give, but I uhh… wanted to let you know I was still thinking of you. Looked touch-and-go for a bit, but we limped across the line. Hope to see you for lunch later this week to strategize on the Inauguration. Let’s try to do better than Robert Frost.”

Bobby tried not to look at the portrait of his brother on the wall. He took a sip from his glass and let its contents burn the inside of his mouth.

“Robert, it’s Jackie. Oh, I’m so sorry that I won’t be able to see you today, but I’m calling from Skorpios. Aristotle and I wanted to wish—.”

Bobby emptied his glass and hit the stop button on the answering machine with a hard swat. The voices vanished. He was alone again. He was alone again in the same room where Jack had spent the final hours of his life. All his friends. All these trappings of power. And what had it all been for? What was it that people even remembered? What was worth preserving?

He could still remember getting the call from his brother Ted, two days after his birthday. He had been staring at the mass of cheery birthday cards in his garbage bin as his brother wept through the phone, “I’m so sorry. Robert, I’m so sorry. In Dallas. They say in Dallas he was—. Oh Robert. Bobby. Oh, Bobby. I’m sorry he’s—.”

“Surprise!”

Lights blazed to life overhead. Robert dropped his glass as time came out of joint. He could suddenly see through the artifice, through the cheapness of the scenery. A paper American flag. A chipped desk. A plastic red telephone. Jack’s portrait. Less objects than a recreation of them. A memory. A haunting.

And then, situated across from him, a mass of faces. Ethel. Moynihan. Unruh. Shriver. Long. Connally. Byrd. McNamara. He stared uncomprehendingly at their smiling faces, at the cake in his wife’s outstretched arms, and then at what lay beyond them, stirring in the darkness beyond him.

“What—?”

“Oh happy birthday, Bobby!” said the crowd as one.

Bobby remained frozen beneath the spotlight. Wheels churned in his head. “You all—.”

“It was my idea, as usual,” said Moynihan, detaching himself from the mass. He adjusted his glasses and gave a bashful grin. “I know you don’t like to make a fuss about these things, but you’ve been running yourself ragged since the Election and we wanted to show you—.”

“That people still remember you, you old bat,” said Unruh in his deep baritone. “After all, how many times does a man turn 47? Christ, you’re finally old enough to fit in here.”

“Old as the Hill,” clucked Byrd.

“Older than Jack ever got to be,” muttered McNamara.

“And with more victories than he ever got,” said Connally in a wry voice. “Two.”

There was a snicker from somewhere in the dark beyond the scene. Bobby’s head turned toward the noise, toward the rows of bodies beyond his reach, rows that seemed to stretch infinitely outward.

“Is that all people remember? Is that what…” He took a shaky step toward the threshold.

“Well, of course,” said his brother-in-law Shriver. “Four more years in control of Washington isn’t nothing. You’ll always have been president. Just like Johnson. Like your brother.”

“What the hell did that bastard do again?” Joked Connally.

“Same as we did, I suppose,” muttered Long.

McNamara stared at his feet. “No great commitments. No great institutions. A yearning for…”

“Things that never were,” Bobby whispered. He felt himself looking out on the edge of some great threshold. If only he could see the faces of the people out there. If only he could touch them, make them understand, take control of the narrative. All those compromises… Lost futures…

He reached out a hand.

“Oh dear, our great communicator’s been rendered speechless,” said Shriver.

“I think he’s just calculating what to say,” said Long with forced cheer.

“Always the politician,” said Connally. “Even on his birthday, always the—.”

Robert felt someone approach from behind and his attention pull itself back toward the stage. He turned. There, standing next to him, was his wife Ethel. She looked at him and gave a sad smile, birthday cake in hand. The candles shimmered.

“Come on, Bobby. Blow out the candles and make a wish.”

“Try not to blow it this time,” said Byrd.

“Close your eyes.”

“Hope for something better.”

“Try to make it a good one.”

There was nowhere else to go. Nothing else to do. He gave one last look across the stage and then to the crowd judging him from beyond. Then, he shut his eyes, took a deep breath, and blew.

Finale

After the days of waiting, the exhausting recounts, the final declarations and rosy press reports spinning his narrow victory, Bobby found himself alone again. He found himself picking confetti out of his suit and returning to his quiet office. He found days melt into weeks and a monotony reassert itself over the White House. Briefings came—about the situation in Vietnam, about the struggling economy, about unrest in the cities. The momentary thrill of victory faded into memory and here, still, he remained. Older but not wiser.

With a brush of his hand, the president clicked the answering machine on his desk. He stood in the dark and waited. There was the whirring of tape and, then, the sudden intrusion of voices.

“Heya, Bob! It’s John McKeithen! I already congratulated you on your victory a few weeks ago, but my secretary told me that it’s your birthday and, hell, I wanted to congratulate you for that as well. Forty-seven! Damn! Still remember your fights as Attorney General, but glad to see you’ve grown up. Tell Byrd I said hello and no hard feelings about Long, would ya?”

Bobby shook his head and retrieved a bottle of whisky from a compartment behind his desk.

“Hi Robert, it’s Terry Sanford. I’m glad we got the chance to talk during your victory party a few nights back, but I thought you’d appreciate some birthday wishes too. A lot of fellas down here think you’re doing a great job. Don’t let the critics get you down, all right? Your family should be proud of what you’ve done.”

Bobby tried not to look at the portrait of his brother on the wall. He took a sip from his glass and let its contents burn the inside of his mouth.

“Robert, it’s Lem. Lem Billings. I uh… know we’ve had our differences, but I wanted to call and see how you’re doing on your birth—.”

Bobby emptied his glass and hit the stop button on the answering machine with a hard swat. The voices vanished. He was alone again. He was alone again in the same room where Jack had spent the final hours of his life. All his friends. All these trappings of power. And what had it all been for? What was it that people even remembered? What was worth preserving?

He could still remember getting the call from his brother Ted, two days after his birthday. He had been staring at the mass of cheery birthday cards in his garbage bin as his brother wept through the phone, “I’m so sorry. Robert, I’m so sorry. In Dallas. They say in Dallas he was—. Oh Robert. Bobby. Oh, Bobby. I’m sorry he’s—.”

“Surprise!”

Lights blazed to life overhead. Robert dropped his glass as time came out of joint. He could suddenly see through the artifice, through the cheapness of the scenery. A paper American flag. A chipped desk. A plastic red telephone. Jack’s portrait. Less objects than a recreation of them. A memory. A haunting.

And then, situated across from him, a mass of bodies. Ethel. Moynihan. Unruh. Shriver. Byrd. Connally. Long. McNamara. He stared uncomprehendingly at their smiling faces, at the cake in his wife’s outstretched arms, and then at what lay beyond them, stirring in the darkness beyond him.

“What—?”

“Oh happy birthday, Bobby!” said the crowd as one.

Bobby remained frozen beneath the spotlight. Wheels churned in his head. “You all—.”

“It was my idea, as usual,” said Moynihan, detaching himself from the mass. He adjusted his glasses and gave a bashful grin. “I know you don’t like to make a fuss about these things, but you’ve been running yourself ragged since the Election and we wanted to show you—.”

“That people still remember you, you old bat,” said Unruh in his deep baritone. “After all, how many times does a man turn 47? Christ, you’re finally old enough to fit in here.”

“Old enough to finally know who here butters your bread,” clucked Byrd with a look of pride.

“Older than Jack ever got to be,” muttered McNamara.

“And with more victories than he ever got,” said Connally in a wry voice. “Two.”

There was a snicker from somewhere in the dark beyond the scene. Bobby’s head turned toward the noise, toward the rows of bodies beyond his reach, rows that seemed to stretch infinitely outward.

“Is that all people remember? Is that what…” He took a shaky step toward the threshold.

“Well, of course,” said his brother-in-law Shriver. “Four more years in control of Washington isn’t nothing. You’ll always have been president. Just like Johnson. Like your brother.”

“And all it took was knowing who was disposable. All those people cast aside,” muttered Long. “But I suppose that’s the Kennedy way. And for what?”

“For power, what else is there?” said Byrd sharply.

McNamara stared at his feet. “Power for its own sake. Leaving behind no great institutions. No great commitments. All yearning for…”

“Things that never were,” Bobby whispered. He felt himself looking out on the edge of some great threshold. If only he could see the faces of the people out there. If only he could touch them, make them understand, take control of the narrative. All those compromises… Lost futures…

He reached out a hand.

“Oh dear, our great communicator’s been rendered speechless,” said Shriver.

“No, don’t belittle him. Our good ol’ boy is just calculating what to say,” said Byrd with forced cheer.

“Always the politician,” said Connally. “Even on his birthday, always the—.”

Robert felt someone approach from behind and his attention pull itself back toward the stage. He turned. There, standing next to him, was his wife Ethel. She looked at him and gave a sad smile, still balancing a birthday cake. The candles shimmered.

“Come on, Bobby. Blow out the candles and make a wish.”

“Try not to blow it this time,” said Long.

“Close your eyes.”

“Hope for something better.”

“Try to make it a good one.”

There was nowhere else to go. Nothing else to do. He gave one last look across the stage and then to the crowd judging him from beyond. Then, he shut his eyes, took a deep breath, and blew.

Follies

Robert F. Kennedy’s world had shrunk to a remarkable degree in the days since the Election. It wasn’t just the agonizing counts, the recounts, the lawsuits and countersuits. It wasn’t the inconclusive nature of the Election, the fact that he had been deprived of both a final, crushing defeat or liberating victory. It was the isolation.

With his allies scattered across the country, meeting with governors and congressmen in the desperate hopes that he could keep his job, and his aides telling him to remain in Washington to “appear in control” and “presidential”, Bobby had little to do but walk the halls. He felt like a ghost most nights, gliding through silent corridors, ruminating on the situation in Vietnam, the struggling economy, the unrest in cities. The few press events he allowed—how he hated the press and their goddamn nattering—left him feeling colder and more alone than anything else. He had no one who understood him. He had nothing to do. He’d be angry if he weren’t so depressed.

Without thinking, the president pushed his way into the unlit Oval Office. He approached the Resolute Desk. He did not dare to look at the stack of newspapers and briefings on the Election but instead focused on the blinking light of his answering machine. Before he could stop himself, he clicked the device and listened as a profusion of voices filled the room.

“Bobby, it’s Kenneth O'Donnell. The plan to swing the Electors was a bust. I’m on my way to talk to the governor but it really looks like we might be staring down the barrel here with the House.” A pause. “I’m sure this isn’t the birthday present you wanted, but I’ll keep you updated if things change.”

At the mention of his birthday, the president felt himself recoil. Such a silly, pointless thing to mention at a time like this. A light flickered somewhere in the room.

“Bob, it’s Larry O’Brien. I guess I should start by saying, happy birthday… Not every day a man turns forty-seven…” The president reflexively balled his fists. Why were people bothering him with this shit? “...but I’ll be meeting with Democratic leaders in New York tomorrow to discuss strategies on the contingent. I’ll let you know if there’s anything productive coming out of that.”

More flickering lights. A surprising heat despite the icy November weather outside. The president cast off his jacket without looking.

“Robert, darling, it’s Jackie. I hope you’re holding up well. I’m following the news about the Election in Greece and it’s just awful. On your birthday too. It’s just—.”

He slammed a finger against the STOP button and collapsed into his chair. Was his birthday the only fucking thing people remembered? The only real achievement he could claim? Was his only fucking merit in life persisting, going around the sun 47 times, being older than Jack ever was when he—.

Bobby gulped. He loosened his tie. It was so fucking hot.

He sat there in silence, hands over his eyes, sweat pouring out of him. It was a moment before he noticed the large stage lights overhead and the assemblage of pieces that his office had been transformed into. A plywood desk in place of the Resolute Desk. A worn roller chair where his high-backed seat should be. A papery American flag and a printed portrait of his brother, eyes cast downward. It was cheap. Tacky.

Across from him stood an array of figures—Ethel, Moynihan, Unruh, Shriver, Byrd, Connally, Long, and McNamara. Performers. Actors. Caricatures with wide smiles and exaggerated make-up. The kind of colorful characters, distorted and boiled down to their most essential characteristics, that might entertain.

Now, they stood as one. In Ethel’s hands was a large cake with lit candles.

“Is this what it was all for?” Bobby growled. “Is this what people get out of me?”

The group said nothing. Candles flickered beneath the intense stage lights. Shapes teemed in the darkness beyond them.

“When you take all of the pretensions away, is this all people commemorate? A birthday party. A young face with a complicated personality. Another fucking morality play to gawk at?”

More silence. Long gave him a pitying look. McNamara stared bleakly at the false portrait of Jack.

“Is that what you’re here for?” Bobby turned his attention past these shadows and toward the things out in the darkness beyond his reach. Row after row, they stretched before him. “A cherubic face and raging turmoil. A dark prince.” He spat the words. “Not anything I actually did or any movement I tried to lead. Not any of the work or… or…”

The mass said nothing. It did nothing. It merely stared at him from beyond the threshold.

““Could you name a single thing I did? A bill I passed? All this for what? To imagine things that never were?”

The silence was yawning. He felt like he could cry but he would not let them see his tears. He would not give them that satisfaction.

“Fuck off.” He turned his back to the audience. He stormed his way through the throng of actors, past a Connally who was more indignant that he had ever been, past a Byrd who seemed almost cartoonish in his bigotries, past a Long who was almost supernaturally weak. He ignored the silent Ethel and the cake in her outstretched hands.

“I’m not done yet. Okay? I still have work to do! I’m going to win this contingent election. I’m going to secure my legacy, Jack’s legacy. I’m going to pass bills and programs and be more than just a fucking name and a face on a wall. I’m not your paper doll. Do you understand? Do you—.”

He turned around but instead of the stage, he found himself back once more in his office. The room was empty. Papers lay scattered across the floor. His heart thumped furiously in his chest.

“I’ll show you,” he muttered. “I’m not done.”

His eyes flitted across the dark room. His eyes rested on the extinguished light of the answering machine.

“I’m in control. I’m the president. I get to say what gets remembered.”

Without another word, the president turned. As he exited the room, the scene once again plunged into darkness.

`) e.executable.push([0, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/K5gwoDP.png'})]) if (songChange != 1) { const endingSongs = new Playlist(); const endingSong = new Song( "Harry Nilsson", "Marry Me a Little", "https://i.imgur.com/1JD1gpy.png", "https://audio.jukehost.co.uk/sAEEMhNr56yzumKr3f9tXXKFLrAOFyZy" ); endingSongs.addSong(endingSong); songChange = 1 changePlaylist(endingSongs); } CONTINGENT = 0 } else if (quickstats[0] < 270 && quickstats[0] > 160) { // RFK Loss if(republican != "hughes"){ e.pages.push(`

Closing

After the days of waiting, the exhaustive recounts, the final result of the election was no longer avoidable. He had lost. Bobby had put on a brave face afterward, had conceded to his opponent who graciously accepted. Then he did what he always did when faced with unpleasant news—he buried himself in his work. Briefings came about the situation in Vietnam, about the struggling economy, about unrest in cities. He continued to issue orders as if they meant anything, as if his actions would not be immediately reversed by his successor. He felt like a child playing dress-up. He wasn’t growing up. He was growing down.

He shut the door to his Office, quiet but firm. He looked around the room, already in the process of being deconstructed for his successor, already with fewer papers sitting in his inbox. The only sight of life was the small red dot blinking on his answering machine. He pressed the “PLAY” button and pretended to work as the tape whirred to life.

“Hi Daddy, it’s Kathleen. I’m sorry I won’t be able to make it down to Washington for your birthday, but I’m just swamped with classes right now. Hope you’re carrying on okay given…” there was a long crackle of static through the machine. “Anyways, just wanted to let you know I was thinking about you. Call back when you have a moment.”

The paper on the top of his pile said something about agricultural insurance programs. Bobby tried to focus on the words.

“Hey, Robert. It’s Teddy. First, uh, happy birthday. I know you don’t like to celebrate it, but I didn’t think I could let the opportunity past by without… I mean 47’s a big one… you know…” More silence. Bobby thought he could detect a slight slurring in his brother’s words, a liquid sloshing around in glass. “You got a lot ahead of you is what I mean. We’ll figure out a way forward. Talk soon.”

There were many graphs in the packet, each illustrating the different outcomes of a possible change in federal regulation.

“Robert, it’s your mother. I know you think you can fool everyone else with the stip upper lip, but I know better. If you thought for a second that I’d let you become an ingrate, your father—.”

The president clicked the answering machine off and allowed the room to lapse into silence. He was alone again in the same room where Jack had spent the final hours of his life. Except unlike Jack, he hadn’t sacrificed anything. He hadn’t done anything that could not be immediately reversed. He’d had all these friends, all these trappings of power and, in the end, what would he be remembered for? A sad, one-term president? A gimmick? What had it all been for? What was worth preserving?

He could still remember getting the call from his brother Ted, two days after his birthday. He had been staring at the mass of cheery birthday cards in his garbage bin as his brother wept through the phone, “I’m so sorry. Robert, I’m so sorry. In Dallas. They say in Dallas he was—. Oh Robert. Bobby. Oh, Bobby. I’m sorry he’s—.”

“Surprise!”

Lights blared to life overhead. He dropped the paper he’d been holding and only now saw it for what it was, a cheap stage prop. He looked around his office to see it too transformed. He could see through the artifice, through the cheapness of the scenery. A paper American flag. A chipped desk. A plastic red telephone. Jack’s portrait. Less objects than a recreation of them. A memory. A haunting.

Then, situated across from him, a mass of bodies. Ethel. Moynihan. Unruh. Shriver. Byrd. Connally. Long. McNamara. He stared uncomprehendingly at their smiling faces, at the cake in his wife’s outstretched arms, and then at what lay beyond them, stirring in the darkness beyond him.

“Oh happy birthday, Bobby!” said the crowd as one.

Bobby remained frozen beneath the spotlight. Wheels churned in his head. “What is—?”

“A birthday party, you old bat,” said Moynihan, detaching himself from the mass. He adjusted his glasses. “I know you’ve been beating yourself up over the Election, but that’s no excuse to ignore a birthday party. I mean, you’re only 47!”

The president circled around his desk. He stared at the congregation and then tried to focus on the things beyond his reach. It was so hard with the blazing stage lights.

“But… I haven’t done anything worth commemorating,” he said in a whiny, child-like voice.

“Who has?” said Connally with a false levity. “Look, you’ll never have Jack’s good looks or his death, but think of how much time you’ll have.”

“So many parties left to go. You could live to be 80! 100!” said Unruh, nodding at the cake.

“Or 120,” said Byrd with a sly grin. “A regular Methuselah.”

“Always lingering,” said Long, his eyes cast downward.

“Time enough for people to forget the bad parts,” said McNamara.

“And only remember the good,” finished Shriver. “All those heady principles. Those speeches.”

“Much easier to celebrate without the actual difficult work of being president,” said Connally. “Maybe you could build some houses.”

The president stared. “That’s what I want. I never wanted to… to just be another face on the wall, to attend dinners and ceremonies for the rest of my life. I wanted to be a vehicle of change. I wanted to show people that greater things were possible. I wanted to show…”

“Things that never were.”

It was his wife’s voice that broke the silence this time. He turned to look at her. She had a strange, sad expression. The cake’s flickering candles made her look ghostly.

“Come on, Bobby, you had your chance,” she said quietly. “All that’s left now is to pick up the pieces and hope. It’s time to blow out your candles.”

“Try not to blow it this time,” said Long.

“Close your eyes.”

“Hope for something better.”

“Try to make it a good one.”

There was nowhere else to go. Nothing else to do. He gave one last look across the stage and then to the crowd judging him from beyond. Then, he shut his eyes, took a deep breath, and blew.

`) e.executable.push([0, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/RvW47iS.png'})]) } else{ e.pages.push(`

Finis

Something was wrong in Washington. Something had broken. All through the White House was a nervous energy, almost manic. His calls to Howard Hughes to concede in the days after the Election had gone unanswered. His Republican rivals had spent the past few days avoiding him and the press. The only voice at all in the election’s aftermath had been Robert Dole, his would-be opponent’s running mate, who emerged from his New York hotel sweaty and pale-faced. He had muttered a few things about a “historic outcome” and “the need to address challenges ahead” before vanishing himself into the Headquarters of the Republican National Convention.

Whatever self-pity he had had for himself had long since been buried by his growing sense of alarm. Where was Howard Hughes? He asked himself as days marched on, as the public became more frantically obsessed with their new would-be messiah, the man who had promised them that he would only appear to them when they had shown themselves worthy. What the hell is going on?

Weeks passed. On November 20th, his birthday, he still found himself trying to grapple with the crisis. Briefings on Vietnam, the economy, the rising unrest in cities sat untouched on his desk in the Oval Office. His attention was focused solely on his answering machine.

“Mr. President,” came the voice of Ted Sorenson. “I’m in Summerlin, Nevada. I’ve been trying to get in contact with Mr. Hughes’s representatives at Summa Corp all day, but I haven’t been able to get through. I’m going to try to force myself into one of their offices around noon today to see if I can’t get their attention that way. I’ll send you an update when I have one.”

The answering machine clicked. A second message played.

“Robert, it’s Ted again. I… I went over to the Summa Corp. Headquarters and forced myself into a meeting. Said I was here from the President and wouldn’t leave, but the meeting isn’t what’s important. It’s—. They’re shredding papers, Robert. I’ve never seen anything like it. The whole building is shredding everything. They’re scared and skipping town. I’ll call you back as soon as I have something.”

Another click. Another message.

“Bobby. My God. They haven’t seen Hughes in years. Not just us. No one. I don’t think he’s in the country. I’m not even sure he’s alive. I know it sounds crazy, but we have a serious crisis on our hands. We might be—.”

The message was suddenly replaced by a terrible grinding noise. Bobby looked down to see his black ribbons of tape emerging from his answering machine, spilling out over the edge of his desk onto the floor. There was the smell of something burning. Acrid. He rushed toward the plug and pulled it from the wall. The grinding ceased and was replaced by the sound of his own heart thudding in his ears.

What have we done? He wondered. What on earth have we stumbled into?

He walked across the room, unnerved by the quiet. The Oval Office felt wrong. There was something wrong with the barometric pressure, like a light breeze just before the storm. Bobby gripped his arms tightly and held himself. He stared up at the enormous portrait of his brother on the wall. Was there something Jack would do now? Was there some wisdom he could leave behind? He racked his brain for some kernel of wisdom, some forgotten truth. Nothing answered him.

Instead, he felt a slight chill. He felt as he did on the last day before his brother had left for Dallas. He had tried to warn Jack. The trip felt wrong. It felt like something terrible was about to happen, like they were both going to stumble into it. There was something violent in the air. But all Jack had done was laugh and insist he was worrying too much. There was nothing to be afraid of. Everything was going to be—.

“Celebrity is a mask that eats into the face,” came a low, guttural voice from behind him. Bobby felt his blood freeze in his body. He did not turn.

Something shifted in the room behind him. It slouched, stumbled, near the space where his desk was.

“But it devours more than the wearer. It eats into the culture as well.”

He did not dare move his head, but he felt as if an enormous spotlight had been turned on both of them. In his mind’s eye, he could imagine it posing as Jack had once posed, arms stretched against the flat surface. A mockery of civic sainthood.

“It devours the past and puts something else in its place,” the voice was so soft he could barely hear it above the thundering of his heart. “It forces us to reinvent expedient gestures as moments of great moral weight.”

There was a long hacking set of coughs. Bobby’s eyes flitted around the place where he stood, but his office suddenly looked strange, unreal. The portrait of his brother was no longer a piece of art but a cheap, printed thing. The majestic flag at the corner of his vision had been reduced to cheap paper. His carpeting had become replaced with nondescript black wood and, beyond that, was an enormous void. One thousand seats stretched out before him, but he could not see who was seated in them.

“Nothing is ever how it was. They took my name and made it into something else.”

The unseen creature, the living corpse, was moving toward him now. He could hear its feet drag themselves across the stage. He stared intently at the flag near the edge of his vision. He stared at the pole.

“They’ll do the same to you.”

The thing was behind him. His hand fidgeted. The impossible audience leaned forward.

Wrap-up

Bobby never had any false illusions about what the result of this election would be. Still, he tried to maintain his dignity. He had conceded early on Election Night, his surrender graciously accepted by his opponent. He had returned to a White House already beginning to thin as staff looked for other jobs and opportunities. He had pushed forward by doing what he had always done—burying himself in his work. He accepted briefings on the situation in Vietnam, on the struggling economy, on the unrest in cities.

He gave speeches and issued orders, trying his hardest to ignore the obvious absurdity of it all. Anything he did now would likely be reversed by his successor. He wasn’t president at all. He was a child playing dress up. He wasn’t growing up. He was growing down. As he looked at the newspapers bemoaning every aspect of his Administration, it felt like the entire nation was doing the same.

Still, he pressed onward. He pressed himself through empty White House hallways, past Secret Service agents who looked at him with a mix of curiosity and sadness. He sealed himself inside his Office, once again ignoring pleas from his wife and his children to enjoy what time he had remaining. He had no intention of doing that.

There was work to be done. Phone calls to be answered. The answering machine on his desk blinked. Without hesitation, he clicked the button labeled “PLAY”. As the tape whirred, he pretended to organize his paperwork.

“Bob, it’s Larry O’Brien. I was surprised to receive your call the other day, but I wanted to return it and, uh, wish you a happy birthday.” There was a pause. Something going unsaid. “I’d be happy to help with whatever project you got cooked up after January, but, uh, let’s table that, alright? It’s only been a few weeks.”

The president scowled. He moved several useless papers from his inbox to his outbox.

“Bobby, this is Jeff Greenfield. First off, congrats on turning 47. Second, I, uh, got your message about wanting to do a Farewell Address. I’m not sure if you’ve seen the polling numbers recently, but we should maybe discuss options before we go that direction. I’ll send you a memo.”

Bobby gathered up a collection of documents and slammed them into his garbage bin. He did nothing when the bin tipped sideways.

“Mr. President, this is Earl Graves. I appreciate you reaching out on your birthday and all, but I don’t think, this close after the election, is the right time to reach out to black—.”

The president jerked the answering machine toward him and hit the “STOP” button with his thumb. The room lapsed itself into silence. He was alone again. He was alone again in the same room where Jack had spent the last few hours of his life. Unlike Jack, there was no possibility of making his presidency mean anything, of the fight for civil rights or economic justice continue. Instead of being martyred for something greater than himself, his defeat had made his ideas smaller and more marginal.

Had Jack feared this? As his car glided down those Dallas streets, had he worried that his vitality would be sapped from him? That he might disappoint the country in ‘64 and everything he fought for and believed in would be forgotten?

He could still remember getting the call from his brother Ted, two days after his birthday. He had been staring at the mass of cheery birthday cards in his garbage bin as his brother wept through the phone, “I’m so sorry. Robert, I’m so sorry. In Dallas. They say in Dallas he was—. Oh Robert. Bobby. Oh, Bobby. I’m sorry he’s—.”

“Surprise!”

Lights blared to life overhead. He dropped the papers he’d been holding and only now saw it for what they were—a cheap stage prop. He looked around his office to see it too transformed. He could see through the artifice, through the cheapness of the scenery. A paper American flag. A chipped desk. A plastic red telephone. Jack’s portrait. Less objects than a recreation of them. A memory. A haunting.

Then, situated across from him, a mass of bodies. Ethel. Moynihan. Unruh. Shriver. Byrd. Connally. Long. McNamara. He stared uncomprehendingly at their smiling faces, at the cake in his wife’s outstretched arms, and then at what lay beyond them, stirring in the darkness beyond him.

“Oh happy birthday, Bobby!” said the crowd as one.

Bobby remained frozen beneath the spotlight. His mouth opened and shut as his brain processed what was happening. “N-No… No, this isn’t…”

“Isn’t what, Bobby-buddy?” said Connally with an exaggerated wink. “Forty-seven is nothing to scoff at. Hell, that’s more birthdays than Jack got.”

“No. No, I mean, this isn’t what I came here to do. I have work. I have so much work to—.” He was rambling, he knew. His mouth felt dry.

“Christ, kiddo, leave the work for someone more capable,” said Byrd, detaching himself from the crowd to pick up the papers strewn across the stage. “Haven’t you made enough of a mess already? I mean, God, the stories people will tell about this…”

“Bobby the fumbler. Bobby the dunce,” said Long, observing Byrd. He frowned. “It doesn’t really have the same ring to it.”

Shriver cut in, “But I’m sure you’ll be around for a long enough time to make it mean something. You could live another 60, 70 years if you’re lucky. By that time, all these fights about Vietnam, the economy… they’ll seem like nothing.”

“Will be nothing,” Byrd corrected, now back on his feet.

“You’ll have your library, your parties to focus on the good stuff like your speeches. All your petty little family dramas. Oh, boy, they’ll get a kick out of the Jack thing. Very cinematic, very theatrical,” said Connally. “They’ll find meaning in that, long after they’ve forgotten everything you stood for.”

There was a guffaw of laughter from somewhere out in the darkness. Bobby spun to face it. If he focused hard, he could just make out the masses beyond those stage lights. Countless generations, all watching him. If he could just reach them, hold their hands…

“No, it was never about any of that,” muttered Kennedy, still staring into the dark. “I never wanted to be just another face on the wall. We were supposed to finish the work. We were supposed to do something, to embody change…”

“Strange way of embodying it,” said Long. “All those compromises.”

“All those dead,” said McNamara in a dark and sullen voice.

There was a long sigh as Moynihan adjusted his spectacles. “Oh, not to worry, Bobby. This country’s yet to find a president it couldn’t add to the pantheon. You’ll maybe not be as bright a star, but you’ll be fine. You lot always are.”

The president took a step away from the stage’s edge. “This can’t be how it ends. It just can’t,” he muttered. “What about all those possibilities we used to dream of? What about those…”

“Things that never were?”

It was his wife’s voice that broke the silence this time. He turned to look at her. She had a strange, sad expression. The cake’s flickering candles made her look ghostly.

“Come on, Bobby, you had your chance,” she said quietly. “All that’s left now is to pick up the pieces and get off the stage. It’s time to blow out your candles.”

“Try not to blow it this time,” said Long.

“Close your eyes.”

“Hope for something better.”

“Try to make it a good one.”

There was nowhere else to go. Nothing else to do. He gave one last look across the stage and then to the crowd judging him from beyond. Then, he shut his eyes, took a deep breath, and blew.

Finis

Something was wrong in Washington. Something had broken. All through the White House was a nervous energy, almost manic. His calls to Howard Hughes to concede in the days after the Election had gone unanswered. His Republican rivals had spent the past few days avoiding him and the press. The only voice at all in the election’s aftermath had been Robert Dole, his would-be opponent’s running mate, who emerged from his New York hotel sweaty and pale-faced. He had muttered a few things about a “historic outcome” and “the need to address challenges ahead” before vanishing himself into the Headquarters of the Republican National Convention.

Whatever self-pity he had had for himself had long since been buried by his growing sense of alarm. Where was Howard Hughes? He asked himself as days marched on, as the public became more frantically obsessed with their new would-be messiah, the man who had promised them that he would only appear to them when they had shown themselves worthy. What the hell is going on?

Weeks passed. On November 20th, his birthday, he still found himself trying to grapple with the crisis. Briefings on Vietnam, the economy, the rising unrest in cities sat untouched on his desk in the Oval Office. His attention was focused solely on his answering machine.

“Mr. President,” came the voice of Ted Sorenson. “I’m in Summerlin, Nevada. I’ve been trying to get in contact with Mr. Hughes’s representatives at Summa Corp all day, but I haven’t been able to get through. I’m going to try to force myself into one of their offices around noon today to see if I can’t get their attention that way. I’ll send you an update when I have one.”

The answering machine clicked. A second message played.

“Robert, it’s Ted again. I… I went over to the Summa Corp. Headquarters and forced myself into a meeting. Said I was here from the President and wouldn’t leave, but the meeting isn’t what’s important. It’s—. They’re shredding papers, Robert. I’ve never seen anything like it. The whole building is shredding everything. They’re scared and skipping town. I’ll call you back as soon as I have something.”

Another click. Another message.

“Bobby. My God. They haven’t seen Hughes in years. Not just us. No one. I don’t think he’s in the country. I’m not even sure he’s alive. I know it sounds crazy, but we have a serious crisis on our hands. We might be—.”

The message was suddenly replaced by a terrible grinding noise. Bobby looked down to see his black ribbons of tape emerging from his answering machine, spilling out over the edge of his desk onto the floor. There was the smell of something burning. Acrid. He rushed toward the plug and pulled it from the wall. The grinding ceased and was replaced by the sound of his own heart thudding in his ears.

What have we done? He wondered. What on earth have we stumbled into?

He walked across the room, unnerved by the quiet. The Oval Office felt wrong. There was something wrong with the barometric pressure, like a light breeze just before the storm. Bobby gripped his arms tightly and held himself. He stared up at the enormous portrait of his brother on the wall. Was there something Jack would do now? Was there some wisdom he could leave behind? He racked his brain for some kernel of wisdom, some forgotten truth. Nothing answered him.

Instead, he felt a slight chill. He felt as he did on the last day before his brother had left for Dallas. He had tried to warn Jack. The trip felt wrong. It felt like something terrible was about to happen, like they were both going to stumble into it. There was something violent in the air. But all Jack had done was laugh and insist he was worrying too much. There was nothing to be afraid of. Everything was going to be—.

“Celebrity is a mask that eats into the face,” came a low, guttural voice from behind him. Bobby felt his blood freeze in his body. He did not turn.

Something shifted in the room behind him. It slouched, stumbled, near the space where his desk was.

“But it devours more than the wearer. It eats into the culture as well.”

He did not dare move his head, but he felt as if an enormous spotlight had been turned on both of them. In his mind’s eye, he could imagine it posing as Jack had once posed, arms stretched against the flat surface. A mockery of civic sainthood.

“It devours the past and puts something else in its place,” the voice was so soft he could barely hear it above the thundering of his heart. “It forces us to reinvent expedient gestures as moments of great moral weight.”

There was a long hacking set of coughs. Bobby’s eyes flitted around the place where he stood, but his office suddenly looked strange, unreal. The portrait of his brother was no longer a piece of art but a cheap, printed thing. The majestic flag at the corner of his vision had been reduced to cheap paper. His carpeting had become replaced with nondescript black wood and, beyond that, was an enormous void. One thousand seats stretched out before him, but he could not see who was seated in them.

“Nothing is ever how it was. They took my name and made it into something else.”

The unseen creature, the living corpse, was moving toward him now. He could hear its feet drag themselves across the stage. He stared intently at the flag near the edge of his vision. He stared at the pole.

“They’ll do the same to you.”

The thing was behind him. His hand fidgeted. The impossible audience leaned forward.

Follies

Robert F. Kennedy’s world had shrunk to a remarkable degree in the days since the Election. It wasn’t just the agonizing counts, the recounts, the lawsuits and countersuits. It wasn’t the inconclusive nature of the Election, the fact that he had been deprived of both a final, crushing defeat or liberating victory. It was the isolation.

With his allies scattered across the country, meeting with governors and congressmen in the desperate hopes that he could keep his job, and his aides telling him to remain in Washington to “appear in control” and “presidential”, Bobby had little to do but walk the halls. He felt like a ghost most nights, gliding through silent corridors, ruminating on the situation in Vietnam, the struggling economy, the unrest in cities. The few press events he allowed—how he hated the press and their goddamn nattering—left him feeling colder and more alone than anything else. He had no one who understood him. He had nothing to do. He’d be angry if he weren’t so depressed.

Without thinking, the president pushed his way into the unlit Oval Office. He approached the Resolute Desk. He did not dare to look at the stack of newspapers and briefings on the Election but instead focused on the blinking light of his answering machine. Before he could stop himself, he clicked the device and listened as a profusion of voices filled the room.

“Bobby, it’s Kenneth O'Donnell. The plan to swing the Electors was a bust. I’m on my way to talk to the governor but it really looks like we might be staring down the barrel here with the House.” A pause. “I’m sure this isn’t the birthday present you wanted, but I’ll keep you updated if things change.”

At the mention of his birthday, the president felt himself recoil. Such a silly, pointless thing to mention at a time like this. A light flickered somewhere in the room.

“Bob, it’s Larry O’Brien. I guess I should start by saying, happy birthday… Not every day a man turns forty-seven…” The president reflexively balled his fists. Why were people bothering him with this shit? “...but I’ll be meeting with Democratic leaders in New York tomorrow to discuss strategies on the contingent. I’ll let you know if there’s anything productive coming out of that.”

More flickering lights. A surprising heat despite the icy November weather outside. The president cast off his jacket without looking.

“Robert, darling, it’s Jackie. I hope you’re holding up well. I’m following the news about the Election in Greece and it’s just awful. On your birthday too. It’s just—.”

He slammed a finger against the STOP button and collapsed into his chair. Was his birthday the only fucking thing people remembered? The only real achievement he could claim? Was his only fucking merit in life persisting, going around the sun 47 times, being older than Jack ever was when he—.

Bobby gulped. He loosened his tie. It was so fucking hot.

He sat there in silence, hands over his eyes, sweat pouring out of him. It was a moment before he noticed the large stage lights overhead and the assemblage of pieces that his office had been transformed into. A plywood desk in place of the Resolute Desk. A worn roller chair where his high-backed seat should be. A papery American flag and a printed portrait of his brother, eyes cast downward. It was cheap. Tacky.

Across from him stood an array of figures—Ethel, Moynihan, Unruh, Shriver, Byrd, Connally, Long, and McNamara. Performers. Actors. Caricatures with wide smiles and exaggerated make-up. The kind of colorful characters, distorted and boiled down to their most essential characteristics, that might entertain.

Now, they stood as one. In Ethel’s hands was a large cake with lit candles.

“Is this what it was all for?” Bobby growled. “Is this what people get out of me?”

The group said nothing. Candles flickered beneath the intense stage lights. Shapes teemed in the darkness beyond them.

“When you take all of the pretensions away, is this all people commemorate? A birthday party. A young face with a complicated personality. Another fucking morality play to gawk at?”

More silence. Long gave him a pitying look. McNamara stared bleakly at the false portrait of Jack.

“Is that what you’re here for?” Bobby turned his attention past these shadows and toward the things out in the darkness beyond his reach. Row after row, they stretched before him. “A cherubic face and raging turmoil. A dark prince.” He spat the words. “Not anything I actually did or any movement I tried to lead. Not any of the work or… or…”

The mass said nothing. It did nothing. It merely stared at him from beyond the threshold.

““Could you name a single thing I did? A bill I passed? All this for what? To imagine things that never were?”

The silence was yawning. He felt like he could cry but he would not let them see his tears. He would not give them that satisfaction.

“Fuck off.” He turned his back to the audience. He stormed his way through the throng of actors, past a Connally who was more indignant that he had ever been, past a Byrd who seemed almost cartoonish in his bigotries, past a Long who was almost supernaturally weak. He ignored the silent Ethel and the cake in her outstretched hands.

“I’m not done yet. Okay? I still have work to do! I’m going to win this contingent election. I’m going to secure my legacy, Jack’s legacy. I’m going to pass bills and programs and be more than just a fucking name and a face on a wall. I’m not your paper doll. Do you understand? Do you—.”

He turned around but instead of the stage, he found himself back once more in his office. The room was empty. Papers lay scattered across the floor. His heart thumped furiously in his chest.

“I’ll show you,” he muttered. “I’m not done.”

His eyes flitted across the dark room. His eyes rested on the extinguished light of the answering machine.

“I’m in control. I’m the president. I get to say what gets remembered.”

Without another word, the president turned. As he exited the room, the scene once again plunged into darkness.
