BuzzFeed

The 5 Kennedys We Most Want to See on the “Things That Never Were” Red Carpet!

Subscribe to BuzzFeed Daily Newsletter

“Broadway delayed is Broadway denied” — Robert F. Kennedy, Sr. (probably)

by Benny Johnson
BuzzFeed Staff

💬 View All 181 Comments

We can all agree that politics nowadays can be pretty disheartening.



Fortunately for us, there’s still a few things that can still bring people together and remind us what being an American is all about.



For those of you living under a rock, Things That Never Were is (finally!) returning to the Broadway stage. After a brief interregnum due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the much-loved sensation about our 37th President is set to return to the Gershwin Theatre—where we hope it will remain forever.

There’s just one question on everyone’s mind. Who will show up for the star-studded, red carpet premiere? While many celebrities (from Mel Gibson to Meryl Streep) have already confirmed they’ll be present for this exclusive event, America’s own political royalty have stayed mum on their plans.

Here’s a list of the top five Kennedys we’re hoping will make an appearance.

5. Joseph P. Kennedy III



Starting us off on the list is POTUS himself, Joseph P. Kennedy III! While some people think that the president should be dealing with “official business” (like the fighting in the West Bank and his stalled infrastructure package), JPK III has always known how to put on a show for the public.

His decision to recreate his grand-uncle JFK’s “We choose to go to the Moon” speech during his last term sent our hearts soaring. His promise to work with Jeff Bezos to get a man on Mars by 2029 gives us all something to look forward to amid looming government dysfunction.

Let’s just hope he visits the red carpet before the red planet!

4. Maria Shriver



America’s princess is all grown up! While some people don’t think of the Shrivers as “real Kennedys”, Sargent Shriver more than proved his Kennedy bona fides during his two terms by using his charisma (and a heavy dollop of old-fashioned American firepower) to resolve the energy crisis of the late 1970s. We thank him for keeping oil prices low and the economy moving.

But more than that, we thank him for giving us his daughter, Maria, who stole our hearts with displays of genuine compassion. After the Cleveland Riots, Maria was one of the first on the scene to express her “sympathy” for those whose bodies were impacted by policing-related bullets. Her dances with King Charles, King Talal of Saudi Arabia, and President Pinochet of Chile showed that America is just as good with soft power as it is hard.

Her status as First Daughter made her revered around the globe. Her marriage to Austrian model Arnold Schwarzenagger set television records. An appearance at the Things That Never Were premiere could do the same.

3. John F. Kennedy, Jr.



The “black sheep” of the Kennedy family, former president John F. Kennedy, Jr., has been sparse with his appearances since his devastating loss in 2004 to Ross Perot. Aside from his lifestyle podcast, his brand deals, and Instagram posts, the one-time, one-term president has been almost absent from American public life.

But there’s been recent rumblings of a Jr. renaissance in Washington. Though his escapades in the Middle East (and in the bedroom!) were once considered to be a black mark on the family legacy, foreign policy experts are starting to re-evaluate the Princeling President’s decision-making. His air strikes against Iraq, Syria, and Libya are now considered foundational to the JPK III “Maximalist Monroe” doctrine. Even America’s right wing (still divided between half-a-dozen small parties built around one or two celebs) consider his military action in Latin America to be “undoing the mistakes his father made in the Bay of Pigs”.

Wow! Let’s hope the Jr. Train keeps chugging into the TTNW station this Friday.

2. Harper, Owen, Nora, and Neil Kennedy



We couldn’t let this list end without acknowledging the cutest members of the Kennedy Clan—Treasury Secretary Patrick J. Kennedy’s heirs, Harper, Owen, and Neil.

During the pandemic, pictures of these kiddos are what kept us going. When lockdown first started, video of Nora bursting into her father’s office made us laugh. When Secretary of Health and Human Services Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. said that the total number of deaths had “exceeded projections”, America was soothed by Nora singing the title song of “Things That Never Were”. When President Romney announced an end to pandemic relief and the stock market tanked, the family released a video from their Cape Cod estate saying they were there for us.

Some think Patrick J. Kennedy should stay away from the spotlight after his alleged run-in with the cops even though he was pardoned and received an apology from the arresting officer. Even if that’s true, we don’t think a single beer should ruin anyone’s life. After all, we’re a country that believes in second chances.

1. The Man of the Hour Himself, Robert F. Kennedy



Finally, we have the man we all want to appear—Robert F. Kennedy himself!

It’s been hard to pin the celebrity president down since leaving Office. After his shocking, near-assassination (beautifully dramatized by Aaron Sorkin in his film Dallas), the Dark Prince of the Clan tried to make himself invisible. He barely did public signings of any bills and even declined to appear for State of the Union Addresses, preferring instead to send a letter (which is technically legal! Every president up until Woodrow Wilson did it!). It was as if the government was running on auto-pilot.

Then, Things That Never Were hit Broadway in 1975. Its meteoric success (despite negative reviews from a few snobby critics) reminded everyone why they loved Bobby in the first place! Inspiring songs, documentaries, and books, the showstopper made sure he could no longer hide. America was never going to move past this 70s icon!

The family makes many statements on his behalf (for example, using him to win support for John Jr’s Invasion of Venezuela and for JPK III’s infrastructure bill). His last major appearance, however, was in 2009 when he made an unexpected appearance at the Robert–Ethel Kennedy Foundation for an event commemorating the 40th anniversary of his inauguration. The icon tried to downplay his celebrity, focusing on boring issues like welfare policy and Vietnam (honk shoo). It wasn’t until a Things That Never Were truefan started asking him about the musical and how it felt to be “an icon” that he became the Brooding Bobby that we all know and love.

“What was it all for?” he cried, inspiring applause from the audience (video here).

That’s an easy question to answer, Bobby. It was all for you!

`) e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/1r6QtGM.png'})]) } else if(shot == 1 && !(debug)){ // Shot e.pages.push(`

Mr. Could-a, Would-a, Should-a

By Alan Smith, a theater director and critic at n+1

In the mid-1980s, Italian writer and academic Umberto Eco began screening the film Casablanca to a group of American students. While never a fan of the movie itself, Eco found himself riveted at how the students would “greet each scene and canonical line of dialogue (“Round up the usual suspects,” “Was that cannon fire, or is it my heart pounding?”–or even every time that Bogey says “kid”) with ovations usually reserved for football games. He wondered why it was that audiences responded with such enthusiasm, why it inspired such fascination despite it being, in his words, “a very mediocre film.”

“It is a comic strip, a hotch-potch,” he wrote, “low on psychological credibility, and with little continuity in its dramatic effects.” Yet, the film was an amazing success, one whose cliches elevated the production instead of diminishing it. The secret, Eco thought, was that the film was made up as it was shot. No one, not even the director, knew what the characters would say or do or which lover Ilse would eventually leave with.

Forced to improvise, the director, cast, and crew “mixed in a little of everything… When the choice of the tried and true is limited, the result is a trite or mass-produced film, or simply kitsch. But when the tried and true repertoire is used wholesale, the result is architecture like Gaudi’s Sagrada Familia in Barcelona. There is a sense of dizziness, a stroke of brilliance.” Casablanca is not just one film, it is many films.

“When all the archetypes burst in shamelessly, we reach Homeric depths. Two cliches make us laugh. A hundred cliches move us,” Eco wrote.

The same could be said of Things That Never Were, the 1977 musical drama whose revival is currently being staged at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre. Written amid the final days of the Robert F. Kennedy Administration, the still-anonymous (and much debated) librettist and lyricist in a little of everything. He threw in the bubbly comedy of How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying. He applied the vignettes and framing device of Company. There’s even a little bit of Cabaret with its tumultuous second act, a sense that the party is over and the world that birthed Bobby Kennedy is coming apart at its seams.

In truth, there is little originality in Things That Never Were, at least nothing that wasn’t done first and better in other stage shows. Yet, much like Casablanca, audiences cannot seem to get enough of it. The current Broadway production is in the middle of a sold-out run, despite mixed reviews. It has inspired no less than five film adaptations and been cited as a favorite by three presidents. It has become so indelibly associated with the American presidency that U.S. Marine Band played an orchestral version of the opening number— “A Fair World”—at Kaine’s inauguration this January, the implications apparently lost on the participants.

Only one recent production of has seemed to understand its subject matter and it was, perhaps pointedly, not done by an American at all. In 2014, Soviet director Kirill Serebrennikov staged an unauthorized production to protest intensifying US sanctions on Cuba and Vietnam and President Harold Ford’s propagation of the POW-MIA myth. In that rendition, audience members, silent and dressed in masks, were invited to clog the stage as the actors performed. Instead of the president’s near-assassination (the most iconic moment of the fictional and real Kennedy’s life), he is instead swallowed by the crowd and vanishes. The play then abruptly ended, without resolution.

What Serebrennikov understood is that Things That Never Were, more than a cavalcade of cliches, is a ghost story. It is a musical that allows America to reflexively, obsessively revisit the traumas of the late 1960s and early 1970s. When Americans see the tortured Bobby, they do not just see the real Kennedy that vanished shortly after his assassination attempt, governing in near silence and solitude. They see sad reflections of his successors—Percy, Hooker, Quayle, Hart, Gingrich, Wilson. They see an endless array of presidents without significant accomplishments, unable to commit decisively to any path. They see a set of fabulous failures whose charisma and glamour disguise a country that is stagnating and out of ideas.

The last major attempt to reimagine welfare took place under Lyndon Johnson. US officials continue to fret about “Vietnam Syndrome” even as they trap themselves in near-identical entanglements across the Sahel. Reboots and reimaginings of decades-old properties dot the popular culture landscape. Turnout at the last election fell to almost 40% as candidates from both parties tried to claim the mantle of the silent, 99-year-old Kennedy scion.

Perhaps the reason why so many find themselves transfixed by this fictional Bobby Kennedy is a hope that he might escape the well of cliches that we too have found ourselves trapped in. We watch him like one watches Orpheus leading Eurydice out of hell, praying that this time the story might be different, that he won’t look back.

We live on the hope of a better ending. We pray for things that never were.

`) e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/FQVuQkO.png'})]) } else if(RFKwon == 1 && CONTINGENT == 1 && !(debug)){ // Winning a contingent election e.pages.push(`

From Partisan to Bipartisan

COMMENTARY OP-ED

Perhaps the most immediate shift in Kennedy’s posture came with his close call victory in the contingent election. It took determination, grit, and working across the aisle to even get him back into the oval office for term two; that was a lesson Kennedy would take to heart. His once flaming heart liberal core would fade away, replaced by a hardened spirit. One which would see America embark on more and greater crises, and would see Kennedy revive his reputation.

Perhaps the first and most immediate reaction to the contested election would be Kennedy’s major initiative, the Scott-Sparkman tax cuts. The beginnings of his bipartisan legislation overhauled the tax code, cutting taxes for the top and middle bracket to encourage greater innovation across America. It also offered greater tax credits and breaks to small business owners, encouraging younger citizens to start businesses.

The second, and perhaps more important of Kennedy’s second term overhauls, brought crime to a screeching halt across America, by enforcing the laws on the books more strictly via the Kennedy Crime Bill. No more would criminals picked up for drug usage be back out on the street just moments later; no, instead, they’d be hauled off to jails, properly preventing the degradation of our streets in urban areas. Packaged along with this came a sharp increase in federal grants for urban police departments such as the NYPD or LAPD, to prioritize their ability to enforce the laws in urban ghettos which had long been ignored.

Nevertheless, the speed bumps presented by the oil crisis slowed down the administration massively. RFK bravely deployed troops to several areas in an attempt to protect American supply lines, but ultimately, he faltered, and gas prices increased further against Kennedy’s wishes.

What came next was a wipeout in 1974. But despite the hostile congress, Kennedy still worked to pass common sense environmental policy, such as the establishment of the Environmental Defense Agency. Ultimately, it’s important to reflect on the lessons learned from RFK term two, and its follow up, the Rhodes Presidency, that centrist governance works; and that even in the worst of situations, one may always come out with a clean few victories by working across the aisle. You cannot understand the Kennedy legacy without understanding the values of good governance.

`) e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/LVbEPmL.png'})]) } else if(RFKwon == 1 && republican == "hughes" && e.player_answers.includes(15672) && !(debug)){ // Beating fully exposed Hughes e.pages.push(`

Sports Illustrated | The Moments That Defined Super Bowl LVII

The magnitude of what happened in last night's game may feel like a blur now, so let us break it down.

With football season coming to a close, another Super Bowl disappears in the rearview mirror. Beyond the game, last night left us with many questions about both teams' directions. After leading his team to a devastating loss, Head Coach Scott Frost's career may be on the clock. Even despite their win, the Washington Kennedys have problems of their own. With MVP RG3 suffering a potentially debilitating injury, they may be on the lookout for a new star player.

Yet when the confetti rained down, the fans roared, and RG3 lifted that trophy overhead from the stretcher, all those questions felt meaningless. The Washington Kennedys have finally done it; after two prior attempts, they secured a historic threepeat in a shutout against the New England Patriots. So, let's focus on the moments that made that night meaningful.

Griffin and Bush's Bromance

Tragically, in the first quarter, the Kennedy's Quarterback, Robert Griffin III, suffered an injury, leaving him with a torn ACL, forcing his removal from the game. In a remarkable show of sportsmanship, a so-called Patriots fan, President Bush, visited Griffin down at the bench shortly after halftime.

Griffin said this when asked about the exchange during a post-game interview: "It was humbling for sure." Speaking on the historic first of a President's visit to a bowl game. "Truthfully, I think it's what we needed now. You know- he didn't show up for himself. [...] Sports shouldn't be about politics, and I'm glad he didn't let any views separate us."
Griffin added, "He asked if I had a cast he could sign. He said he'd brought a sharpie down and everything," inspiring sparse laughter in the room. After a pause, Griffin inserted, "I think he was joking."

The President and MVP continued their pleasantries through the night, with the President retweeting Griffin's celebratory tweet on the @POTUS Twitter handle.

Robert Griffin III @RGIII
1d

Humbled. GOD WINS.

💬 1.2k 🔁 8.1k ❤️ 101k


Griffin's kind post-game words must not have reached these fans, however, who burnt an effigy of the President in the streets of Richmond later that night.

Broadway Invades Boston

Though no one hopes for an artist to bomb in front of the largest audience in the country, critics' expectations for Jake Novak were set at historic lows. However, when he opened with the title track from Things That Never Were, all gripes of anybody watching were laid to bed instantaneously.

Novak proved that Broadway has just as much right to headline the halftime show as even the hottest stars, like Rush and Mumford and Sons. Novak brought a range of emotions with his setlist, from the cheerful Las Vegas, to the dreary End This War. Perhaps Novak's most memorable performance was reaching out his hand toward President Bush's seat in the audience, sinking hearts across the country.
Through his performance, Novak used the field as a stage, bringing Bobby Kennedy to our TVs at home. Shoving his ensemble out of the way as they ran aimlessly through the field during The Phone Is Ringing, Novak showed the terror of the Hughes Affair through his expression that we just don't get during biannual election season broadcasts of the show.

The Unforgettable Ads

It's become a ritual for some Americans to try and spot each Kennedy family cameo during advertisements. Some advertising firms now go as far as to include the information of the family's agents with a purchase of 30 seconds of ad time in a package deal.

Last night, astute Kennedy watchers could have achieved a new high score, with different family members appearing in a whopping 16 ads (not including Ford's new Kennedy F250).

The funniest, which immediately dominated the conversation on Twitter, the everything app, was the sibling banter between Matthew and Joe III in their Sonic ad.

The most shocking reveal, however, was saved for last. In the final ad break, John Kennedy Jr. made his first public appearance since 1995. After facing trial for dropping out of the 1992 presidential election after a bet with his brother, the President and Democratic nominee, John retreated from public life to protect his sister's career, the then newly appointed Secretary of State Caroline Kennedy (who still holds this position today!)

While the politically astute debated the ethics of his appearance, the rest of the country was reminded of the first time they were ever charmed by the ever-boyish looks of "John" from State Farm.

With John emerging from his private life, the lid on the Kennedys' Pandora's Box has opened wide! Many Kennedywatchers are placing bets online on who could appear next, with some eager fans using AI to imagine what ads RFK would be in if he were alive today!

`) e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/5pVJPtr.png'})]) } else if(RFKwon == 1 && republican == "hughes" && e.player_answers.includes(15644) && !(debug)){ // Beating partially exposed Hughes e.pages.push(`

Community Project: Let’s Fix Things That Never Were

livejournal.com
12 June 2018 - 02:12
👤Bratty Byrdie

Things That Never Were is not a great musical. It is not even a “good” musical. Still, there is no doubting its power. Even if you haven’t seen it, you probably do recognize the songs “Las Vegas” and “Elusive”. A few years ago, JPMorgan Bank tried selling credit cards with a cover of “Give ‘Em A Show”—a song that’s extremely sarcastic in context.

The world just can’t get enough of this show and it’s hard to blame them. Aside from its compelling source material—based on the epic debacle that was the 1972 presidential election—-the show tries to deal with some heady topics related to politics, greed, and our desire to see the best in people who don’t deserve it.

Or, at least some versions do. Over the years, there’s been no fewer than 12 major staged productions with wildly different interpretations. There’s the original Broadway stage version portraying 1972 as an epic struggle between fantasy and reality. Then there’s the British stage version that tries to turn 1972 into a kind of “epic tragedy”, a moment when “America reverted to its youth” after the traumas of Vietnam and the Kennedy Assassination. Then there’s the American version that treats the material entirely as a personal struggle between two Great Men, where the nation is merely a canvas for them to color. And there’s the Soviet staging that—.

Aaagh!

People like the grand ideas. They like the larger-than-life characters, but 50 years after its original premiere, it’s clear that something is missing from this show to help it hold together. Not to sound too much like a LaRouche girl, but it feels like we still don’t know the whole story. Maybe someone should ring up 93-year-old Bobby Kennedy and see what he knows.

I don’t know. The point of this blog is not to relitigate things (I got flamed enough for my take on the 2000 election and how the FBI was totally involved in stealing it from poor Jack Jr.). It’s to offer a way forward for the TTNWerewolves to brainstorm a way to fix this musical.

Below, I’ve created a cute little table compiling all publicly available info on the major productions of TTNW, organized by differences in plot, song changes, and other miscellaneous stuff. I’m thinking if we look at the differences between these different shows, we can figure out what works and what doesn’t. Maybe we could even write our own script given that they’re talking about reviving it again at the Kennedy Center this year.

What do you think? Let me know if you notice any changes that should be made below.

VersionNotable plot differencesNotable song differencesOnly this version includesMiscellaneous notes
Broadway stage version (premiered on Broadway, 1975)
  • Both acts set in Washington, DC
  • Each act concludes with a separate election, with Act I ending with the midterms and Act II ending with the 1972 election
  • Rogers Morton is the primary antagonist throughout the show and “Howard Hughes” represented only in silhouette and pre-recorded narration
  • Bobby wins with no suggestion of foul play
  • Rogers Morton humiliated by sham election and forced from his position
  • The song “Party Man”
  • The character of Bobby Kennedy is only referred to as “The President”
  • Clifford Irving” as a character has not yet been conceived.
British stage version (premiered in the West End: 1978)
  • Act I set in Washington, DC; Act II set in Las Vegas, Nevada
  • Instead of Rogers Morton as the antagonist, Clifford Irving is added as Kennedy’s adversary and Morton is portrayed as his enabler.
  • Subplot added where Ethel keeps running into the predatory J. Edgar Hoover
  • Bobby wins, at cost of compromising his principles
  • Irving flees the country, with Morton left to face criminal prosecution
  • Addition of 12 new songs
  • Reorderings of songs
  • Significant alterations to the score
  • These songs:
    • “Cocktail Party”
    • “Ghost”
    • “One Last Chance”
    • “No Return”
    • “Ghost (Reprise)”
  • The character of Nixon (mentioned in original production)
  • Tim Rice recruited for rewrites of the book and lyrics
  • The character of Bobby Kennedy is referred to as “Bobby” for the first time
  • Long and Byrd serve as a comic Greek chorus
Soviet stage version (premiered at the Rossiya Central Concert Hall, 1991)
  • Both Acts take place on Election Day
  • Bobby played as merely putting a softer façade on the sham offered by Irving
  • Long portrayed as a Cassandra-like character whose warnings are dismissed and who is forced to contend with the encroaching influence of Byrd
  • Kennedy wins after revealing himself to be no better than Irving
  • Irving escapes with no implication that he will face justice
  • Most comedic songs removed from this production
  • The song “The American Machine”
  • Major additions to the book to emphasize the role of Vietnam in the hysteria over Hughes’s nomination
  • Politics made the central element of the production
  • The show uses one set, styled after the Oval Office
  • Ethel completely removed as a character
  • John F. Kennedy appears as a ghost who watches the proceedings silently
  • Morton does not appear as a character
  • Controversy in the American press amid a visit by President E.M. Kennedy led to its abrupt cancellation.
Swedish stage version (premiered in Stockholm 2003)
  • Prologue set in Dallas, the rest of the story takes place in Las Vegas over the course of the final month of the 1972 campaign
  • Bobby and most of the other cast are aware of Irving’s deception from the outset
  • Ethel subplot entirely reworked to center on her growing anger at her husband’s complicity in the sham
  • Bobby wins after revealing himself to be no less duplicitous than Irving
  • Epilogue depicting the 2000 Election Controversy, implying Bobby’s “dirty tricks” have set the stage for later political crises
  • Omission of 6 British songs
  • Various song alterations
  • Most songs rewritten with new lyrics
  • The songs:
    • “If He Cared”
    • “Too Late”
    • “Things That Never Were”
  • Johnny Carson used as a narrator
  • Rogers Morton only appears as a voice over the telephone and is implied to be embezzling party funds
  • Significant reduction of the cast, with Long removed entirely
  • Re-centers politics as the central element and makes Bobby Kennedy the “most instrumental figure of the 20th century” (for better or worse)

`) e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/sJhJQAx.png'})]) } else if(RFKwon == 1 && quickstats[0] == 538 && !(debug)){ // Kennedy 538 EVs e.pages.push(`

🔖 Examining the Kennedy Legacy


We’re coming up on the 56 year anniversary of the first ascension of Robert F. Kennedy to the oval office. Since then, it’s been almost 14 elections of pure, unfiltered popularism and rejuvenation of the American spirit. It’s important to evaluate the background of Kennedy and how he came to be the true champion of America.

Beginnings


The start of Kennedy’s career has been poured over more times than I can count. In that, I will give a brief summary; Kennedy worked with McCarthy, repented, and then worked under his brother, became Attorney General, and then became a senator. Blah, blah. This is basic curriculum; you and I have both seen this in school constantly. We move into 1968, then, where Kennedy eked one of his only real close victories in his career against Richard Nixon. After what seemed like a tough first term, however, his major victories began in 1972, with a clean sweep of 538 votes. From there, America seemed to fall in love with the renegade Kennedy. To move onto more interesting times…

The Changing Decades


Throughout the 70s and 80s, America went into a state of flux. While he kept a consistent VP through his second term, things became rougher as he appealed for a third. Nevertheless, the states let him. The 538 electoral vote landslide in 1972 sent shockwaves through America, and it had come with clean sweeps of every chamber of congress. Now it came that every politician tried to chain themselves to him, seeking greater rewards. In that, America saw greater unification than ever, even through the tumultuous crises that rocked the country. The 22nd amendment was appealed, and after a third term rocked by stagflation and the oil crises, the Vice President of the past made way for a new name; Robert Redford.

Redford was different from the political creatures that dominated his term 1 and 2, and 3. An actor, primarily, and a bleeding heart liberal (to a degree). Initially primed as Kennedy’s successor after his fourth term, the prospect faded as Kennedy claimed that ‘his work was not done’, particularly in the time of the booming eighties.

America returned Kennedy to office in 1980 against a weaker Republican Party, leading into his next term of domestic success and further prosperity after the struggles of the 70s. But Redford retired after one term, citing a want to return to acting and, now, producing. In came Ralph Nader with Kennedy instead; it signalled Kennedy’s want to continue forward with his progressive direction. At least, that was the plan until Nader quickly resigned.

It’s still unclear what happened in that timespan. But later that year in 1985, Gary Hart was nominated to replace him, now guiding American forward under his newer vision. More than ever, America would be focused on the development of technology, particularly under his more innovative, “Atari” branding from the flaming, cultural liberalism of the Redford years.

That lasted about three years, until Hart also resigned. The culture was confused, even with Kennedy’s steady hand to guide them along in his now fifth term.

The Sorenson Years


In came the longest lasting man yet; Ted Sorenson, to replace Hart after the 1988 election. Under Sorenson and Kennedy, the land boomed for a long, consistent 21 years. Gay marriage was legalized in 2008, despite Kennedy’s gaffes on the congress floor in support (which I cannot repeat here). Sorenson was clearly set up to be Kennedy’s next up, with many expecting Kennedy to either resign or pass away in the 1989-2010 timespan Sorenson served.

But he just… didn’t. And for the better, too. Kennedy’s strong will, even in his elder years, kept America powering through into the age of Kennedy prosperity. Kennedy, on his part, seemed well enough to continue, talking up that, despite his many years, he still had things to do. There was an America to continue to oversee. And for his part, he continued to be rewarded with more terms. By this point, much of the opposition to his own presidency had faded; the political fight was spent on congress, rather than over him. He was a goliath.

On Sorenson’s part, he shepherded another twenty years of successful legislation through, seemingly accurately having his ear on public opinion. But it was quiet. So is there much to talk about? No, not really. But that’s fine, in the end. Because it was successful.

But, eventually, Sorenson died in 2010, having his lords calling earlier than Kennedy did. The office sat vacant for three years, with Kennedy seemingly trying to adjust to the giant gap that Sorenson left in the Vice President’s office.

The New Era


But his departure pulled America out of the static place it had been in for so long. It was, then, no shock in 2012 when Kennedy said he was running again. The Vice President was most shocking; this time, it was Melinda Gates, who would now become the first female to ascend to the office. In this, she embraced the culture surrounding abortion and LGBTQ+ rights.

Things moved as normal for a few years. All was quiet, until Melinda stepped down in 2016. A rumor popped up in the corn field of Kennedy allegedly being “sick and tired” of her ardent liberalism. I find the rumors rather doubtful, after his many, many years of activism.

But nevertheless, in came another tech executive; Mark Zuckerberg, the head of Linked. Zuckerberg brought things back down to a quiet simmer, rather than the loud activism of VP Gates. It was all business until 2020, when Zuckerberg left to return to the private sector. Again, he was dogged again by a rumor now alleging that Zuckerburg was too much of a “bore” for the elder Kennedy, on top of allegations of improper usage of office. Perhaps Kennedy had his heartbeat on public approval, as he tended to. That left Kamala Harris, the first senator since Gary Hart, to inherit the office.

Kennedy is now near 100. It is unclear if he intends to stop anytime soon. He has been seen less and less in public since Sorenson’s death. And when he does appear, he does make gaffes; some evidence of this is evident in his DNC appearance in 2020, in which he accidentally called Kamala Harris a word I also can’t repeat, and then seemed visibly confused when he was told that it was not okay for her to be referred to that way anymore.

But that doesn’t particularly matter, nor has it ever around Kennedy and his often occurring gaffes since 2000. Kennedy is the giant the office always needed; the monolith, the rock of stability even in the roughest times. We don’t need a dictatorship for such things. But it’s become clear that America much prefers his brand of stability for as long as he’ll survive. I can say that, as a collective, the country only wants him to live longer. He will be the model for generations to come; greater than FDR, greater than Teddy, and greater than George. He is the star of the show. And nothing will ever come close to him again.

`) e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/LfcPgRf.png'})]) } else if(RFKwon == 0 && (quickstats[0] == 0 || quickstats[0] == 3) && !(debug)){ // Kennedy 0 EVs e.pages.push(`
New York Times

Mr. Kennedy Goes to Broadway


Nov. 10, 2005

Nobody was surprised when it was announced Things That Never Were, one of the most successful Broadway musicals in history, was making a big comeback for its 30th anniversary. A cultural touchstone, the great political thriller and tragedy show was sure to attract a star-studded audience of attendees at its premiere on November 4th. Great actors like Tom Cruise, Leonardo DiCaprio, and Jodie Foster. Power players like Mayor Sharpton and the nominees for Mayor from both parties; Congressman Anthony Weiner and former Frasier star Kelsey Grammer. One man few, if anyone, expected to be there was former President Robert Kennedy.

Something of a recluse since becoming the first President in American history to lose every state in a campaign (only saved from total oblivion), Kennedy didn’t attend the opening show in 1975, despite multiple invites and attempts to contact him by producers. He has few remarks even acknowledging the show’s existence, having claimed in 1975, before Things That Were Never became one of the most profitable productions in Broadway history, that it would “likely be a failure” since “nobody wants to watch a political sob story that ends in tragedy.” Kennedy was proven wrong quicker than he could have ever realized.

In hindsight, it isn’t difficult to see why, after a Greek tragedy and aura of mystery permeated around Kennedy after his historic loss, Things That Never Were became as popular as it was. During its inaugural show in November 1975, hundreds came from all across the nation to watch the sad story of Robert F. Kennedy. His idealism, which critics have called “corrupted” in the show, the rise, presidency, and ultimate fall of a man once considered the most beloved person in the world. Although many said that it told a “fake history” of the events that transpired only a mere month after writing began, for the idea that would become Things That Never Were.

In his only other public comments on the product, Kennedy claimed in 1995 that he agreed with the criticisms, and others close to the former President say he nearly sued them in 1974, potentially stopping Things That Never Were before it ever took flight. Many have expressed confusion at Kennedy’s distaste for the songs chronicling his life, as most historians agree that it is, overall, biased towards Kennedy and the many stories his aides produced in the immediate years after 1972, but many historians, such as popular conservative columnist Patrick Buchanan say that it distorts his ideology.

“Bobby Kennedy wasn’t some kind of anti-Cold War hero who supported the gays and wanted to establish some kind of socialist utopia.” Buchanan said in a recent article, “I was around back then. Kennedy, both Jack and Bobby, they were real warriors. Really tough people. You’d never see someone like [President] Bill Bradley going against the radicals in his party.” Buchanan, like others, view Things That Never Were as nothing more than “left wing propaganda” written by “drugged up communists” during the mid 70s. These sentiments, although not the same charged up partisan statements that men like Mr. Buchanan make, are reportedly shared by Kennedy, who was described in ‘Exiled King: The Fall of Bobby Kennedy and the End of Camelot’, as a bitter, bigoted man in his years since leaving the White House.

All of this is to say that Robert Kennedy’s appearance at a showing of Things That Never Were elicited gasps from those eagle-eyed viewers watching stars enter Broadway for the 30th anniversary show.

Few people could see the man of the hour in the theater, in a dark corner above the audience, locked away from society. Nobody could speak to him. Those who caught a glimpse of him during the show described his expression as “bored”, “disgusted”, and “miserable”.

Towards the end of the show, right before the climax with “All Good Things Must Come To An End”, Kennedy and his entourage stormed out of the theater. At first, members of the cast, and those in the audience who saw him leave, were worried he left out of hatred for the show. However, according to a source close to the President, he had a panic attack and could barely stand on his way out of the building.

“He’s getting up there in age, and he just can’t handle these things the same way, reliving that kind of failure. It’s got to hurt. Nobody has been through as much as he has.”

Robert Kennedy, his family, and the Robert F. Kennedy Foundation all refused to comment for this story.

Watch What Happens Live with Andy Cohen | July 27 2011 transcript

Andy Cohen: Finally, Donald Trump has done it all. Produced Tony award winning Broadway musicals, been one of RuPaul’s fiercest celebrity judges on Drag Race [audience cheers], and is even considering…running for office? [gasps] But, Here’s What, is he ready to [audience chanting] Plead the Fifth!?

Donald Trump: Absolutely.

C: Donald Trump, I have three questions for you, and you can plead the fifth to only one. Trump, say three nice things about…Patti Lupone, [audience jeers] oh no!

T: Well she’s a very nasty woman, very nasty. I’m a good friend with Andrew, so-

C: Andrew Lloyd Webber

T: Andrew Lloyd, we call him Andrew Lloyd, and what washed up has-been Patti Lupone [audience boos] did to him on Sunset, excuse me, excuse me-

C: The audience is not liking that answer, but go on.

T: Thank you, what she did on Sunset, it was a disgrace. A big fat disgrace. If anyone else behaved like that, they would have been kicked the hell off Broadway, it’s true. It’s so true. [tentative applause]

C: Okay, I haven’t heard one nice thing though [audience laughs].

T: I promise you, I actually love standing next to her, it’s true, I do. Because she’s one of the people who makes my hair look flattering. [audience laughs and cheers]

C: Oooo okay-

T: See this is easy, no fifth, no fifth, not pleading the fifth.

C: Well let me give you this one then, what is your all-time favorite musical? And you can only pick one.

T: There’s a lot of them, and I’ve been to a lot of them, believe me. With regard to Cats, we love Cats, but I would say…Things That Never Were [one audience member cheers]

C: Oh wow, is that the, that-

T: Kennedy, yeah, it’s the Kennedys. And let me say, frankly, with respect to the Kennedy, they’re all-time, okay? All-time. With Jack and little John-John, that’s what we call him, we call him John-John. Straight out of central casting, we’ve never seen a man like that, better looking even than Tom Cruise. [audience cheers] Better than Tom Cruise. And it’s very sad what happened to John-John, but people come up to me, tears in their eyes and they say “sir, he’s never really gone,” and I say “wow.” So we’re looking into that very very strongly.

C: Woah, what? You mean-

T: But Jackie, of course, she’s unbelievable, right? [audience applauds] The greatest of all time. Beautiful woman. I mean what she went through, in the pillbox, the little pink, we love the pillbox by the way, love the pillbox. [tentative applause] But you see all these women, beautiful women, who try that look, and let me tell you, no one does like it her. Okay? Nobody. [audience cheers] And a lot of them tried, believe me. Should I say who? [crowd yells yes] No, no…I won’t say it, I’ll be nice.

C: Right, haha, but I mean she’s the best, the best there was, but let me ask you a little more about this play, because I don’t think a lot of people know anything about it-

T: Well they should, they should. It was, okay, it’s about Bobby Kennedy, right? People call him, back there, they all call him [Trump imitating someone] “It’s Robert Kennedy, sir, Robert F. Kennedy,” I say no, no, it’s Bobby. We call him Bobby. [audience applauds]. So it’s about him, with regard to White House, and a lot of birthdays, many many birthdays. He has a song about Vietnam, it’s funny by the way, nobody ever talks about Vietnam. I was telling Ivanka that the other day, remember that? They were chanting in the streets, marching, saying “this is Kennedy’s war,” and I thought wow, we gotta get the hell out of there, and we did. We did. Bobby did it. So that’s what the show is about. You know this right?

C: Uh, sure [audience laughs]. One last question, since we’re on the political topic, we’ve got a big election coming up next year, okay? And everyone’s talking about how, you know, Michael Kennedy, is he running is he not running. So let me ask you, if he calls you up tomorrow and says ‘Hey Donny baby, do you want to be my veep?” What are you telling him?

T: I would tell him, Mike, sashay away. [deafening cheers]

`) e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/Zir91ax.png'})]) } else if(CONTINGENT == 3 && !(debug)){ e.pages.push(`

The WeeklyStandard | The Kennedys Take Saigon

Plus: Why the left can’t stand ‘Things That Never Were’

T. Swanson McNear Carlson
FEB. 19 2002

First, before we discuss the Broadway revival of Things That Never Were, a few words about the ongoing defensive military operations underway in Venezuela are necessary. While we at The Weekly Standard have made our disagreements with President Hogan clear, as he has intensified his anti-democratic intentions at home, it is hard to truly object to the toppling of a corrupt dictatorship threatening our shores thousands of miles away. The dynastic rule of one of the world’s most rotten autocracies is at an end, and it was the United States that did it. That warrants celebration, no matter how cynical the commencement of these operations by Hogan may be, particularly to distract from his impeachment saga and his sex tape scandal.

But that is precisely why the left is outraged over Things That Never Were, the musical reimagining of the Vietnam War and the second Kennedy presidency. Just ask anti-American radical Susan Sarandon, who told Entertainment Weekly that “it’s all fiction, just propagandistic garbage.” She would know a thing or two about that, with her treasonous support for Central American peasants the U.S. rightfully slaughtered. But you can’t expect Hollywood liberals to understand what Real America wants. And as I waited for the curtain call sitting inside the Ambassador Theatre, I looked around the room, seeing everything the anti-American left hates: good white Christian men who have come with their families from the heartland, to see their president rightfully represented as a man wronged by his own allies. Like Caesar, Robert Kennedy was surrounded by enemies.

While bowled over by the musicality and craft of the production (the breathwork Bebe Neuwirth demonstrates, my God), I couldn’t help but fixate on a different element, and that was how the production reveals the truth of those Kennedy years. In the marketing for Things That Never Were, the play has been referred to as a “reimagining” of the presidency, but respectfully, I think that’s entirely wrong. It does not create anything new out of whole cloth, but rather shows us what we always suspected, what we always felt, but could never put our finger on. That very thing is what led millions of us to believe that something had gone awry. That the American story as we knew it had taken a wrong turn somewhere around Saigon.

In this new revival of the classic 1970s production, Robert Kennedy is a man who lured the feeble-minded New Left youths to support his campaign in ‘68, since they still constituted a necessary component of the Democratic coalition. Once in office, he believed he could swat them aside and successfully pursue the Twilight Struggle against the Soviets, as he urged his brother to do in Cuba. But by allowing a parasite into the White House, it consumed him, jamming knives into his back, and having these traitorous filth abandon our brave soldiers in the line of fire. Once Saigon collapsed, the boat people fled, and our last helicopters took off, Kennedy was confronted with the magnitude of his own actions. As imagined in the musical, he told McNamara, “Oh God. What have I done?”

Yet the American people put their faith in him. One. More. Time.

The men of the heartland understood what their president had fought for. They trusted his leadership at a time of crisis. They remembered the Bobby Kennedy of their youth. The man who wasn’t content with staring down the Soviets over missiles in Havana, but wanted to nuke them. The man who was unsatisfied with sending advisors to South Vietnam, and wanted to nuke them. The man who was infuriated at Johnson’s inaction during the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia, and wanted to nuke them too. That man is who I saw on stage last night, and he is someone I would not hesitate to vote for in this climate.

I implore all readers to see this production as soon as you can. It’s not only technically brilliant, but a political revelation, and will change how you have seen the last 30 years of our history. Godspeed to our Marines in Venezuela, Cuba, Nicaragua, El Salvador, Kosovo, Colombia, Iraq, Iran, Georgia, Chechnya, Pakistan, Afghanistan, Yemen, Syria, Lebanon, and Judea and Samaria.

`) e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/ZOraUMZ.png'})]) } else if(RFKwon == 1 && e.player_answers.includes(18800) && !(debug)){ // Nationalize Energy, Win e.pages.push(`

Things That Never Were
TV Mini Series - 2021 - TV-14 - 1h
Description
In the late sixties and seventies, America will go through crises it will have never experienced before. One man fights back against them.

`) e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/fHKTzFy.png'})]) } else if(RFKwon == 1 && econCrash == 1 && !(debug)){ // Economy Crash, Win e.pages.push(`

INSURGENCY BROADWAY!

Elizabeth Wright
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Just after 11 PM on Tuesday, November 22, hundreds of armed cops descended on Zuccotti Park. Wall Street Insurgents were thrown out of their tents, dozens were arrested, and the entire atmosphere of the insurgency had changed forever. It marked the four-month anniversary of Insurgency Wall Street, when the 99% finally began fighting back against the 1%, just as the indigenous people’s liberation armies across Latin America and Africa continue to do as we speak. Much has been written about this sickening sweep by NYPD’s fascist thugs, and all of it is necessary reading, yet one aspect elided much of this coverage, and that was the outdoor performance of Things That Never Were.

A forgotten Broadway musical from 1976, Things That Never Were adapts the crises of capitalism in the early 1970s, set against the backdrop of the second Kennedy presidency, featuring lively scenes of the fascist imperialist war on Vietnam, the FBI’s repression of the Black freedom movement, and of course the economic collapse of 1972, in which millions lost their jobs and homes. This era is crucial to study for any member of the 99%, as we hurtle towards a repeat, with our failing oil wars in Venezuela, Colombia, and Angola coinciding with a capitalist system pushed to the breaking point. Whether it will be revolution or repetition is another story.

The musical examines exactly how the ruling class wormed their way out of such crises, polarizing the working class along issues of race or gender, dividing and conquering. To the detriment of the people, it worked, with the following decades dominated by culture war politics, ignoring the rich fleecing the rest of the nation once again. Something to keep in mind when politicians like Buddy Roemer try to dismiss this people’s movement as “just a bunch of queers.”

Of course few saw Things That Never Were so clearly at the time. Its satirical elements and lampooning of the capitalist ruling class were met with confusion by middle-brow Broadway critics, and with minimal foot traffic, the ambitious production closed shortly after its opening. But the past few months has seen a reclamation of this story, both online and on the ground, with frequent revival shows performed in the park, sometimes by stage actors quitting their typical jobs to come join the rest of the 99%.

We hardly expect all of the working class to appreciate this stage play’s greater meaning, nor should we neglect the important work our insurgency movement is doing in other respects, but Things That Never Were helps encapsulate how fleeting these moments can be. We must not miss this opportunity again. There are few moments in history where as many crises have coalesced to provide the ground for a revolution, but this is one of those times. As the progressive Senator Robert Byrd memorably tells Patrick Moynihan: “even if it takes another hundred years, mark my words, we shall rise again.”

Us insurgents must take heart in Mayor Jim Cramer’s recent prediction at a press conference, declaring that if our movement continues to pick up speed, “nobody’s stopping them, and it’ll be our heads in the street.” Cramer couldn’t be more right. Maybe he would have learned why if he he had watched Things That Never Were.

EDITORS NOTE: This article was published on November 28, covering the police raid on the 22nd, which failed to shut down Insurgency Wall Street. However, on November 29, a much larger NYPD raid combined with FBI agents on the ground dragged away thousands of insurgents and successfully killed the movement.

`) e.executable.push([2, (() => {e.image = e.image = 'https://i.imgur.com/Dgaz4qv.png'})]) } else if(RFKwon == 1 && e.player_answers.includes(9296) && !(e.player_answers.includes(8988)) && !(e.player_answers.includes(9709)) && runningmatefullname == "Russell Long" && vietnam == 4 && econCrash == 0 && badShit == 0 && badShit == 0 && !(debug)){ // Golden Ending e.pages.push(`


Chaney High Seniors Delight in ‘Things That Never Were’

⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀NEWS⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
APR 11, 2024
⎯
SARAH WILLFORD
The president of the United States is grappling with a difficult war abroad. His advisors give him contradictory advice, intent on making him a vehicle for their own goals. As the nation roils, the president wrestles with his demons and tries to figure out what kind of leader he wants to be.

Believe it or not, this isn’t a summary of television’s latest political thriller, but of a rare musical, being performed for the first time in decades by Chaney High School Students, on Fridays and Saturdays from March 12 to April 13.

“Things That Never Were” is a musical that takes place against the backdrop of the presidency of Robert F. Kennedy. Set in the days before cell phones and national insurance cards -- when the “Good Old Boys” of the ex-Confederacy still had their foot on the throat of most Americans, the musical depicts the 37th president as he struggles to secure re-election.

Along the way, he has to contend with a variety of enemies trying to thwart his ambitions -- from the predatory Robert Byrd (Senator of West Virginia, 1959 - 2001) to the corrupt J. Edgar Hoover (Director of the FBI, 1935-1971) to the deceptively friendly D.P. Moynihan (presidential advisor and later President of New York University). All of them have their own interests.

A musical about a popular, then-sitting president seems like something that would catch public attention but not so.

When it was staged off-Broadway in 1975, the production was a bomb, ending after fewer than 20 performances and a slew of bad reviews. Few of the performers ever returned to the stage afterward. Vindicator reporters could only find one other production in the last 50 years -- staged at the Belmont Community Theater in York, Pennsylvania in 1997.

The entire musical might have been forgotten after that, had drama teacher Harry Niles not discovered an old script during school renovations this summer.

“This was the best impulsive decision I ever made,” said Niles. “This show is magic with this group of kids.”

He explained that the show was not the original choice for the Spring musical, but he was encouraged to pursue it by his fellow teachers union members who felt that it would be a great way to combine student interests in history, theater, and politics.

Torrey Moshfegh, a CHS senior who is playing Ethel Kennedy, told Vindicator reporters that students in his drama club didn’t believe Niles when he told them they were producing “Things That Never Were”.

“He told us we were doing this weird, political musical instead of Annie, and, at first, we were all like ‘Whaaaaat?’ Then we started reading the script and the whole atmosphere changed. It was like the characters were in the room with us.”

Niles said all his students showed immense professionalism. He was heartened by how students engaged with the material and asked questions about the topics it raised.

“Before doing this, I don’t know if I thought much about Robert Kennedy because he died in a plane crash in like 1981, decades before I was born,” said Mohammad Osman, a CHS Senior playing Bobby Kennedy. “I started doing a lot of research into him as we were doing rehearsals and I learned a lot.”

“Obviously, he made a lot of mistakes and said stuff I don’t agree with. I think his attitudes on Palestine and gay people were kind of bad. Still, you know, there’s stuff to learn there. He wasn’t perfect, but he tried his hardest. He helped a lot of people. I have friends who still rely on the FAP so it was cool learning where that came from.”

Laura McDaniel, CHS history teacher, says she was excited about “Things That Never Were” from the very beginning.

“I knew even before auditions that we were going to have a great cast. The kids of this generation are just wonderful. They’re so active and involved,” said McDaniel.

She explained how she was so excited by the final product that she reached out to the John F. Kennedy and Robert F. Kennedy Presidential Libraries and offered to send them a recording that they can use for their collections. While neither has responded to her request, she said she remained hopeful.

“Even if they’re no longer the center of the political universe and the family is out of politics, John and Robert Kennedy are well-regarded by historians and have done a lot to foster the next generation of leaders. I hope they can support the Youngstown community by elevating these kids.”

Still, many of the high school students say they’re happy with what they’ve made -- even if it doesn’t get their names in lights at the Kennedy Center.

“I take pride in it. I think we did a good job and it shows that we’re able to challenge ourselves and grow,” said Joshua Stein, drama club student playing Robert Byrd. “I’m hoping I improved my public speaking enough to make a real difference in the Tillman presidential campaign this year.”

“Things That Never Were” will have its last show on Saturday, April 13th. Tickets are available for purchase for $5 on the school website and support the Chaney theater program. All funds will be matched by the Federal Arts and Cultural Heritage Fund.
